name: Jabberwocky: a diceless battle game for fantasy armies
description:
Tactical scale tabletop miniatures game. A diceless mechanic means A always beats B always beats C... but B can get advantages to beat A, etc.

For instance,
Double ranked pikes can not be defeated in frontal attacks
but
Blades defeat Pikes in frontal attacks

Therefore, you CAN defeat double ranked pikes in a frontal attack if the attacking unit is Blades. Similarly, you read down a list of conditions until you get to the first applicable one & use the result.

Figure scale & numbers, & base sizes, are left up to the player. The intended standard game size is 10 stands. Rules allow for play of historical battles, but also include rules on monster types & abilities, magic effects, etc. A number of army lists and a point-build system are included.

name: Hanukkah Pyramideto
description:
The second expansion of Pyramideto - this time with twelve Jewish months and holidays theme. With Hanukka Pyramideto you get 12 new goal cards to the game. As in the Original Pyramideto you move the magical pyramids to form your secret goal.

Twelve cards of Hanukka Pyramideto corresponds to twelve months of the Jewish years and their holidays. All cards have a typical six-color frame, Hebrew name (both in Hebrew and Latin letters), pyramid form and the sign - little Menorah.

Hanukkah Pyramideto is playable also separately.

Integrates with:

Pyramideto

name: Sansi
description: In whole card game of Sansi, everybody plays at the same time and everything is spinning around the quick reflexes and decision making. Players try to pick up and gather in their hand at least three cards of one number/color. This is done by changing one card from hand for one that lies on the display. When player have full a set of numbers ready, he play them straight on to the order cards. Players must decide, if you they keep three cards in hand with chance to have four in time or play it to block order card for others.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Set Collection, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Élisez-moi !
description:
Vote for me! is the game on the presidential election where all cards are inspired by real events and characters.

Each player is a candidate here ą presidential election and must earn popularity points to eliminate his political opponents.

To do this, there are action cards to act on the curve polls.
As soon as all candidates have reached the maximum number of points, they will enter the televised debate in which they will answer the questions, a quiz that will determine their skills and knowledge.
Finally, they will compete in a final duel, the second round of elections, after which elected the new President of the Republic.

name: 6 Memory Skills Board Games
description:
From the publisher, Smart Kids:
"Memorise, Match and Spot the Difference with this revolutionary set of 6 x A3 Memory Skills Board Games! Practise linking techniques for memorising lists; spot picture differences and visually match the same cavemen and dinosaurs to move around exciting game boards. If that’s not enough for one set, the other 3 games contain opportunities to memorise patterns, position and pictures. Don’t forget to tell everyone you know about these brilliant new games, with everything you need to play included in the box. Fun for all ages! Minimal Reading Required - once the instructions have been read, all you need to do is play and have fun!"

name: My Barter Game
description:
My Barter Game is a fun interactive game for ages 7-700.
How to play
Players roll the dice and land on a square, say the accountant which allows you to buy a trade card. Trade card have values on them of cash or trade and are able to be redeemed at the location listed. You only start this game with $100 cash and $100 trade so you need to use your trade to get you cash. When you go around bottom line (our start) you have to pay $200 in cash (one of the rare things in this game that specifies cash as opposed to being able to use either for anything).

There are twists like shark attack or gold mine where you either earn a fortune or loose one.

Everything in My Barter Game is trade-able so if you want to continue play and someone needs help you can bail them out, or if they are on a square you hold the card to you can trade them something.
categories: Deduction, Economic, Educational, Negotiation, Party Game

name: Scared to Death
description:
Scared to Death is a horror monster battle card game for 1 to 4 players. The goal of the game is to battle your way through an opponents monsters and steal all of their precious victims. When a player has no victims left in play, they lose the game and their opponent is the winner!

Scared to Death uses the Ignats Card System; a battle card system designed by October Games that enables players to play with an infinite amount of cards in one match. Players may choose to play a quick game by each using one, 28-card deck, or they may opt for a longer, more complex game, where each player uses five, 28 card decks! Using multiple decks makes it possible to “level up” your monsters, making them stronger over the coarse of the game... yeah, you heard me: your cards can level up like characters in a video game. Level 9 is currently the highest, although the system is designed in a way that makes it possible to release more expansions in the future; meaning your cards could level up infinitely!

The game was designed for 2 players, although variations for 1, 3 and 4 players have been added. Most games that claim you can play solo, end up being designed for 1 person, leaving players feeling as if they are playing a solo game alongside other players. This system uses a card driven AI, so when you are playing solo, you still feel that you are playing against another person. Of coarse the artificial intelligence is not as smart as a human brain, so the AI is given some special advantages to make it a worthy opponent. The four player variant is simply a 2 on 2 battle, that feels almost the same as a 2 player game, but you are partnered up with a teammate, with whom you can trade cards and devise strategies.

Further, Scared to Death can be played using only the cards, or with an add-on betting system that uses tokens, money, or even Halloween candy! Overall, the Card System opens up a wide range of possibilities, including new, and entirely separate games that can be played using your existing Scared to Death cards.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Grid Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: The Chronicles of Abakan: The Titan Campaigns
description:
Welcome to the dystopian future of The Chronicles of Abakan: The Titan Campaigns, a new board game based on the visually stunning and evocative world imagined by the brilliant international sculptor and painter, Luca Zampriolo. Set in a resource-starved future, The Chronicles of Abakan centers around a world controlled by dynastic corporate families who rule through an apex of technology: HDMs (Hard Doll Machines), powerful mechas that serve as both industrial laborers and military enforcers.
The most powerful of these families is House Weingart, a tyrannical and fascist regime whose monopoly over advanced HDM technologies and, most importantly, the super-efficient refined fuel known as “Wein,” has granted them a long-standing and unchallenged authority…
…until now.
Deep in the solar system, where Wein is fueled on distant planets, the colony of Terra Nova has rebelled. Hailing mostly from North America, the Neo-Terrans have summoned the revolutionary spirit of their ancestors and successfully repulsed their Weingart overlords, and now an interplanetary Civil War has begun.
The Chronicles of Abakan is a world of mercenaries and warlords, of bounty hunters and generals, and revolutionaries and military soldiers. Where HDMs drop from transport ships high in orbit around distant planets to do battle on strange and alien terrains, from the crumbling streets of New York City to the frozen tundras of Saturn’s moon Titan, and beyond.

So join in on the strategic and tactical boardgame pitting players against one another in an attempt to secure their dominion or their freedom in a merciless civil war set in humanity’s grim future. The Titan Campaigns chronicle the early years of the Neo-Terrans’ revolution, where players battle for control of resource giving holdings in the Novan Sector, near Saturn. Moons, asteroids, and space stations serve as the battlegrounds, and players maneuver against each other by moving their fleets around the Campaign Map, building up shipyards, factories, and refineries and balancing their resources with expansion and military might.
When battle is engaged, players move to tile-based battlegrounds, pitting their HDMs (Hard Doll Machines)–giant weaponized mechs–against one another. These miniatures are based on Luca Zampriolo’s original designs, and the models themselves are sculpted by Luca Zampriolo himself, as well as Filippo Zanicotti of Dust Tactics fame. When a player conquers his opponent’s holding, he adds it to his own, thus increasing his 4 Resources: Labor, Oil, Iron, and Wein until only one player is left standing.
The board game is set to have two factions: The oppressive Weingart Dynasty and the Neo-Terrans--choose your side today!

name: Majas alfabetsspel
description:
Swedish "Go fish" type card game.

One deck of card, consisting of the letters of the alphabet in small and bid sizes. The players take turn asking the other players after a specific card, trying to get a two card set collection of each letter (one nig and one small letter). The most sets when the deck has run out is the winner.
publishers: K. Hjelm Förlag AB, Rabén & Sjögren

name: The Twentieth Century Limited
description:
Spin and move on a train track from New York to Chicago. Produced in the 1930s. Win the greatest number of points in a previously determined number of trips or be the first to obtain a total of 1000 points.
The board is actually the inside bottom of the box.

name: Night & Day
description:
Looking for something different with game play that seems familiar? Like playing spades or hearts, but want to spice it up a bit? Night and Day is an exciting new trick taking game that throws in a little suspense each round of the hand!

Cards have two values, one for the day and one for the night. Players play a card each round with the intent of being the highest value to take the trick. But no one knows if it’s night or day until everyone has made their play…

name: He-Man and the Masters of the Universe Battling Warriors Game
description:
He-Man and the Masters of the Universe battle the evil Skeletor to save Castle Grayskull from it falling into the hands of evil.

Players choose to defend the Kingdoms of the evil Skeletor or mighty He-Man as they battle against each other or as a team! Each player has matching pairs of their Character Tokens and three Safety Tokens. In addition to these tokens are the Lose a Turn Tokens. Each player has two tokens that can make the other player lose a turn if knocked down.

Game play consists of players sitting 5ft apart from one another and taking turns firing their Battle Weapon. Players try to knock down matching character pairs. First player (or team) to knock down at least three matching character pairs wins!

Each player gets their evil or good side (Skeletor or He-Man) character tokens and places them on the character token strip. Each character token has an individual marked place where they’re token will be placed.

name: La Bonne Carte
description:
There is game board with a spiral path what ends on the center of the board.
Each player gets hand of cards (red, blue, green, orange or white) numbered from 1 to 10. The number of the card determines the movement of the player, the color corresponds to the colors of the boxes of the route. After distribution, the upper card heel indicates the trump suit.

In each round, all players choose one of their cards and pose face down in front of them. All cards are opened and the strongest card wins the trick (the trump outweighs the other colors). Only the player who wins the trick moves his pawn as many spaces indicated by the card., it is necessary that the color of the card matches the color of the box when the pawn arrives.
The white cards are bonus cards in which the color is optional.

The winner is the player who reaches to finish first.

name: La Boîte à Bac
description:
Similar to La Boîte à Quiz.

Topics are Literature, Science, History, Geography, Arts, and Sports. A thick booklet contains extensive responses.

The Box provides 80 cards with about 150 questions. Each card contains a fact and number of questions on a common theme.
Answer correctly and score a point. The player with the most points wins.

name: La boîte à énigmes vampiriques
description:
Another version of the La Boîte à énigmes. This riddles about vampires.

Players or teams compete in puzzle-solving (sometimes timed, sometimes not) in order to score points in different categories. The first team (or player) to score a point in 4 of the 6 categories wins the game.

Every turn, the current player/team draws a card and hands it to the Dealer, a non-competitive figure that reads it aloud and then manages the competition between the people trying to solve the riddle.

name: Laste Mälumängudoomino lisakaardid
description:
68 additional cards with 680 questions for Laste mälumängudoomino

Laste Mälumängu Doomino (Trivia Dominoes) is a boardgame that puts a trivia element into the well known dominoes game. The tiles have two categories marked on them, out of total ten. The tile placement follows normal domino rules, but each time you are placing a tile, you have to answer a question on the topic marked on the tile in question.
categories: Children's Game, Educational, Expansion for Base-game, Trivia

name: Mälumängudoomino lisakaardid
description:
68 additional cards with 680 questions for Mälumängudoomino

Mälumängu Doomino (Trivia Dominoes) is a boardgame that puts a trivia element into the well known dominoes game. The tiles have two categories marked on them, out of total ten. The tile placement follows normal domino rules, but each time you are placing a tile, you have to answer a question on the topic marked on the tile in question.

name: Max on Tour
description:
A cooperative game for young children that focuses on colour recognition and dexterity.

Background story: Max, the snail, travels the world. He meets new friends and is given lots of gifts in different sizes, weights and shapes. He wants to bring them home before caterpillar Rosi has eaten all the lettuce.

Aim of the game: The players cooperate in trying to get Max and his presents home before it is too late.

Setup: The six round cards - five showing one of Max' animal friends and one showing the garden in which Rosi lives - are placed in a circle. The six lettuce chips are placed on the garden card. The colourful gifts (mostly wooden objects but also a pillow and a blanket) are placed in the center and Max' journey starts. He is placed outside the circle of cards, next to the garden card.

Gameplay: Players take turns rolling the die. If a colour is rolled, Max (a wooden plate with stalk eyes and a semi-circle shaped house) is moved with a wooden pushing rod along the circle of cards to the animal of that color. Then a gift of the same colour is loaded onto Max. If the next player rolls the same colour, he/she must push Max one full circle. If there is no gift left in that colour, the die is re-rolled. If a star is rolled, the player may choose any colour and doesn't have to move Max.
If Max loses a gift (i.e. it falls down while Max is being pushed), one lettuce chip is turned over and the gifts are put back on Max.

As soon as gifts in all five colours have been loaded onto Max, the active player returns him to the garden. If there is at least one head of lettuce left, the players win the game.

name: Moorhuhn: Sockenschuss
description:
A press-your-luck and bluffing game with a Moorhuhn (German "Crazy Chicken" computer game franchise) theme.

Components: 58 number chips, 14 Moorhuhn chips, one sock

The number chips show values from 1 to 4 and come in 5 different colours. The Moorhuhn chips are the same size but show the chicken. All the chips are put into the sock, from which the players draw them, trying to collect as many victory points as possible.
Players take turns drawing a chip from the sock. If it is a number chip, the player chooses if he/she wants to continue or keep all the chips he/she has drawn this round. The active player continues drawing chips until he/she either decides to stop, or he/she draws a Moorhuhn chip.
When a player decides to stop, he/she gets to keep the chips drawn this round, sorts them into colours and puts them into rows so that the other players can see them. Black is a joker and the player has to decide which colour he/she wants to use the black chip for at the end of the round.
If a Moorhuhn is drawn, the player's turn ends and he/she doesn't get any chips that round - they go to the next player instead.

The game ends when the last Moorhuhn turns up. Each player counts the point in their row with the smallest number of chips. The player with the most points in that row wins the game.

In a variant players get to keep the chips if a Moorhuhn turns up, but they have to give their row of chips of the same colour as the Moorhuhn to the next player. Scoring is also different: The player with the highest number of points in any of their rows wins the game.

name: SMS 4U
description:
Players use number combinations to decipher which words these combinations would produce on the keypad of a mobile phone.

Players take turns rolling a six-sided die (numbers 1-4, x, "no reception"). The active player rolls the die. If he/she rolls "no reception", the die is passed on to the next player. If a number is rolled, the red token is advanced the corresponding number of spaces on the board and all players try to work out the word marked with that number on the top card at the same time. The first player to correctly guess the word earns the number of chips specified on the card. An x on the die roll means that the active player chooses which of the four codes on the top card has to be deciphered.

The game ends when the red token passes the finish line. The player with the most chips wins the game.

name: Sound Hunt Phonics Game
description:
A set collection game where the object is obtain 3 cards of the same sound in a set. The player with the most sets wins the game.

Players start with 5 cards. The rest of the cards are placed face down on the table. If a player has a set of 3, they can place it on the table right away, then draw 3 more cards. After this is completed, the main game begins.

On each turn, the player asks the others for the sound for which they are hunting. If they complete a set upon receiving cards, they can ask for another sound and continue until they cannot make a set. At that point, the player is told to "go hunt" and they draw a card. If this card completes a set, the player can draw again and continue until they cannot make a set.

If the player runs out of cards, they get 5 new cards.

The player with the most sets wins the game.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Word Game

name: Quartiles
description: Players take turns rolling dice and matching them to sets of up to 4 orthogonally-adjacent tiles selected from an 8x8 game board. Matched tiles are claimed by each player in an attempt to be the first to claim seven sets of four tiles arranged in different patterns. Players earn bonuses for being the first to claim a pattern and for collecting sets of like-numbered tiles.

name: Island Gods
description:
For thousands of years, the island gods slumbered. Now, mortals have arrived, bringing with them the power of belief and the hunger for the miraculous. The gods now vie to become the chief deity of these islanders through enacting various miracles to fulfill the community’s needs, to inspire the creation of shrines, and to shape the very earth to advance their own divine message and thwart the blasphemies of the other gods.

Players take on the role of these gods. The game centers around manipulating the mortals by performing miracles such as the creation of manna, idols, and auras, transforming the landscape, and acquiring the power such miracles require. After each player has performed miracles for the turn, some of the mortals act, randomly selecting from the options of exploring, praying, or enshrining idols.

Players earn victory points through the mortals' prayer, the enshrining and worship of their idols, and through providing the manna for the island's feasts. However, players can subvert the victory point race by vying to gain enough zealous worshipers to win the game outright.
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Point to Point Movement

name: Knives & Axes
description:
The goal is to get "a golden axe & knife".

Each player has five cards may have a knife or an axe, besides each of these will have a number between 3 and 10.
Players throw a card knowing that must be of equal or greater number of which is in the discard pile.
If a player can not play this move, will take all the cards from the pile and the player who threw before he will take as many bronze axes and knives as cards of them have had that pile.

The bronze axes and knives can be exchanged for the same silver (8 bronze axes = 1 silver axe / 10 bronze knives = 1 silver knife), and silver is exchanged for the same golden (2 silver axes = a golden axe / 3 silver knives = a golden knife).

name: Game of Nations
description:
Card game using representations of four continents as the suits, Europe, Asia, Africa and Europe.

The suits have 13 cards. Special cards rank higher, in this order. Map, Man, Woman, Child. These are called the Titles. A random card is selected and that suit are trumps, here called Stars.

It is for four players divided into two teams and is essentially Whist. Players must follow suit, can trump, etc. Every trick above 6 scores a point. There are also bonus points for Titles. After the deal before play begins, should your side have all the four Titles in the Stars suit, your team scores four extra points. If three of them you score 3 points. Two each per team scores nothing extra.

The game also includes rules for playing The Game of Monkey. Any number can play. Take out one card at random. The value of that card means that only three others are in play. Deal out all the cards that are left. In turn a player may discard any pair in his hand on to the table, calling out, say, "A pair of Maps" or "A pair of sixes" and so on. Then the next player throws out a pair. If a player does not have a pair, he draws a card from the hand of the player on his right. Eventually, using this mechanic, all the cards will be matched as pairs except for the Monkey, the card drawn at random at the start.

The player holding the Monkey at the end - quote "rejoices in the pleasure of being called the 'Monkey'. Curiously, it doesn't say if the 'Monkey' wins the game or loses it. If it is a 'pleasure' I suppose he wins.
publishers: Canada Games Company Lmt., McLoughlin Brothers

name: More Peanuts!
description:
In "More Peanuts!", each player will have a herd of elephants whose objective is to collect as many peanuts.

Each player will start at a different point on the board (already marked) and throwing dice you can move up to six different elephants to collect peanuts. In addition, the board has special spaces where players can advance more places, adding trappers on the board, or pull water from the lake.

The objective of the game is to collect the peanut with six elephants and keep them coming back to your starting point.

name: Game of the Mayflower
description:
Historical card game, featuring episodes in the life of the Pilgrim Fathers on their arrival in the 'New World'. The cards are divided into 4 suits of 13 cards and numbered A through D.

All 52 cards are dealt completely out to any amount of players. The player to the left of the dealer goes first and must begin by placing a card numbered either 1 or 13. If the player cannot set a card of that number down then he or she receives a penalty point places a counter in the Pool) and play moves on to the next person. This player can lay a 1 or 13 card down of any letter or may lay a 2 on a 1 or a 12 on a 13 on a matching letter, if the first person was able to set a card down.

Players continue to set cards down by the sequence of numbers on matching letters going forward or backward. If any players are unable then penalty points are given and play moves on. Once the Lettered series gets to 1-6 and 8-13, the 7 is placed to complete the series (only once the 6 and 8 are both played can the 7 be placed across).

The first player to get rid of all their cards, wins the round and scores one point for every card held in all the opponent's hands. The first player to get 15 points, wins the game.
publishers: Cincinnati Game Co., Fireside Game Co., Merrimack Publishing Corp.

name: Hanky-Panky
description:
Card game for adults, based on Poker.

OFFICIAL HANKY-PANKY CARD GAME INSTRUCTIONS: Choose dealer. Deal moves clockwise after each hand. The dealer deals out five (5) cards, one at a time, FACE DOWN, to each player. Male player(s) arrange cards upright to indicate Female articles. Female player(s) arrange cards upright to indicate Male articles... After examining their cards, each player MAY discard up to four (4) cards to improve their card hands... The dealer serves player(s) that number of cards to restore player(s) card hand(s) to five (5) cards. .. Players need not draw; players may play the cards originally dealt to them for the showdown.


THE SHOWDOWN - Each player must show their full card hand FACE UP on the table. THE WINNING CARD HAND DETERMINES THAT CERTAIN ARTICLE(S) OF CLOTHING MUST BE STRIPPED. If playing MALES vs FEMALES or TEAMS, the team with the highest-ranking hand WINS. Each player on the losing team must STRIP the indicated articles. . . If playing PLAYERS vs PLAYERS, the player with the highest-ranking card hand WINS. All other player(s) must STRIP the indicated articie(s). Each loser strips only ONE article per card hand, and ONLY the article(s) indicated by the WINNING card hand. If the WINNING card hand indicates article(s) already stripped, or a MISDEAL occurs, then REDEAL.

name: Spots and Stripes
description:
Match the spots and the stripes, playing one card at a time next to another on the table or the floor.

THE DEAL: Spread out the whole deck, face down. Each player draws six.

THE PLAY: Anyone begins by putting any card he has drawn face up. The next player (to his left) matches either end, by putting a card with the same number of spots or stripes beside the first card, in a straight line or at an angle. Or else you may use one of the Wild Cards. Tiger and Zebra match any number of stripes. Leopard and Giraffe match spots. Turtle in Cage matches anything. When you play a Wild Card, say how many spots or stripes it has, and with the Wild Wild Card, also say if it is spots or stripes. If you can't match from your hand, draw from the rest of the face-down deck, till you can.

THE WINNER: The first to use up all his cards, or the one with the fewest cards when the deck is used up.

name: Legend's Gauntlet
description:
Based on Lost Worlds game system designed by Alfred Leonardi. The 30th Anniversary edition is based on the Robin Hood theme. Two books contain 2 characters each, are case bound with over 120 combined full color illustrations by Doug Shuler. New layout for easier gameplay. Still compatible with all Lost Worlds series books.

Legend's Gauntlet: Sherwood Forest includes
Robin Hood
Maid Marian

Legend's Gauntlet: Nottingham includes
Guy Gisborne
The Sheriff of Nottingham

name: Wendell 7
description:
From the Wendell 7 Website:

Wendell 7 is an educational card game that focuses on mathematical addition for students of all ages. Game play can be easily tailored to age/skill level with 3 levels of difficulty (Junior, Senior 5, Senior 7) and an adjustable time limit.

The goal is to problem solve and work either alone or with a partner to strategically gain the optimum score of seven points in each round. In the Junior Game, this score is attained through using a hand of five cards and using addition of 1, 2 or 3 cards to reach a total of 7, 17, or 27. There are other goals which require strategic management of cards in order to achieve extra points per turn.

"This game isn't just for people who score the highest marks for Mathematics in a school examination, it's for everyone! Those who can analyse the cards in their hands and add up quickly and accurately will be the winner, and those who struggle will learn and improve very quickly."

name: Highway Travel
description:
HIGHWAY TRAVEL is played while riding along the highway in an auto and may be played by two to four players.

Shuffle the cards and deal each player ten cards. After the cards have been dealt, players begin to locate objects along the road that match the cards in their hands. Upon seeing an object, the player should show the card, point out the object to the other players, and lay down the card from their hand. A player receiving duplicate cards in their hand may lay both cards down at a time upon seeing the object.
The first player to lay down all of their cards WINS THE GAME. Special note: A player with the Road Hog card may lay it down upon seeing one auto pass another going in the same direction. Highway Numbers and Speed Limit amounts do not have to correspond with the numbers on the cards.)

The game also includes rules for playing Road Hog, which is Old Maid but the Hog card is the one you do not want to end with in your hand.

name: Ab in den Stall
description: The game consists of task cards, which show an animal and are placed openly on the table, and animal cards, which show three different animals and are dealt to the players. The players place one of their animal cards on the table. If three of the same animal can be found on the table, the player who notices touches the dog meeple and names the animal. The player gets an animal card as a reward. If he or she can find another set of three animals on his or her collected cards, s/he can take the task card. When the stack has been played through three times, the players count their points: An animal card counts one point, a task card counts three points. The player with most points wins.

name: Stapelkönig
description:
The game consists of 36 6-sided dice.

At the start of the game, all 36 dice are rolled. Each player takes a die that shows a 1 and puts it in front of him/herself. Then he/she takes a die showing a 2 and stacks it onto the first die. This continues until the 6 has been reached, then it's back to 1. All players act simultaneously and each player is only allowed to take one die at a time. Sooner or later, a player won't be able to find a dice with the correct number. He/she has to wait until the other players are also stuck. The left-over dice are rolled again. If a tower topples over, the dice are put into the pool for the next roll.

The game ends when all dice have been stacked. The player with the highest tower wins the game.

name: Sprüche klopfen
description:
A trivia game in which proverbs/sayings have to be completed.

Each player puts a player token on one of the empty spaces on the board. Players then take turns rolling the die and move their pawn accordingly. If they land on Hein-Blöd space, they roll the die again to decide which of the six proverbs/sayings printed on the top card they will have to complete. Their neighbour reads the first part of the proverb/saying on the top card and the active player tries to complete it correctly. If they succeed, they win a winner chip (if on a coloured Hein-Blöd space) or a Hein-Blöd chip (if on a white Hein-Blöd space). Three Hein-Blöd chips can be exchanged for a winner chip of the player's choice.

The game ends when a player has collected all six differently coloured winner chips. He/she wins the game.

name: Game of Tight Rope
description:
Game probably inspired by the feats of Charles Blondin, the man who walked across the Niagara Falls on a tightrope. Did you know that he was crossing the Falls and at halfway he stopped and cooked and ate an omelette?

The game is to be played with dice. Throw the dice, each player in turn, until one of the dice is a 1, at which time place a button on No. 1 space, and throw again for a 2. Should neither of the dice be a 2 or the sum of the two dice when added be 2, move down one space, and the next takes a turn. Always endeavor to throw the next number to the one you are on, and move down one space for each throw that you miss. When the party throwing is below the top numbers, and succeeds in throwing the number thrown for, he places his button on the number near the rope. When any doublets are thrown, it is a move to the top and next number. Continue on until you gain No. 12.

name: Antartic Treasure
description:
After collecting a large amount of food, the penguins have returned to feed his family. In "Treasure Antartic" [sic] penguins reach their shelter to get the victory.

Each player will control your penguin and must travel around the game board to the end using move cards (for walking and jumping) and dices (to slide). Players can also take action cards where action may "rest", "pushing another penguin" or "seal control".

To start the game, the Penguins have 10 fish (energy to move on the board), which will be losing while advancing around the board (the rest energy can be recovered). The first player to reach the end of the board with at least 3 fish wins.

name: Dodge the Dragon Card Game
description:
A card game for children. 49 cards are shuffled and dealt face down. Players sort their cards and place any pairs face down on the table. If a player has three cards that are the same, he keeps one card in his hand and places the pair face down on the table. If a player has four matching cards (2 pairs) he can put all four down on the table.

Player to the left of the dealer goes first. He makes a fan out of his cards and holds them, face down, to the player on his left. That player chooses one card from the fan without seeing it. If the card makes a pair with a card he has in his hand, he can put the new pair face down on the table. If not, he keeps the card. Now he fans out his cards for the player sitting to his left. Play continues in a circle, with players choosing cards and putting down pairs. Once a player has played all of his cards, he is safe.

The object is to discard all of your cards and not get left holding the dragon. The game is over when everyone has played all of their cards. The player left holding the dragon loses.

name: BWAH!: Those Left Behind
description: An expasion for BWAH! (and/or BWAH! Can't Stop the Signal) based on the Dark Horse Comics miniseries of the same name. This expansion includes 15 more characters and 36 more cards. Also included are three blank character cards to add your own creations. This expansion also adds the "Hands of Blue" icon.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Sum Sum
description:
A simple die rolling, colour matching and memory game for young children.

Components:
- 12 wooden tiles (printed on both sides)
- 1 six-sided symbol die
- 1 play mat
- 1 winner's medal with holder

Aim of the game:
To collect as many nectar droplets as possible.

Setup:
The play mat is placed at the center of the table. The wooden tiles are mixed and randomly distributed on the mat, with the flower side. (The tiles all show a flower in one of four colours and a bee on one side, and one, two or three nectar droplets on the other side.)

Gameplay:
Players take turns rolling the die. If the die shows the rain cloud, the bees can't fly and the player's turn is over. If the die shows one of the four colours, the player takes a tile with a flower of that colour. He/she looks at the back of the tile and shows it to the other players so that they also see how many nectar droplets there are. Then he/she puts it down in front of him/herself, with the flower side up. Then it is the next player's turn. If the nectar symbol is rolled, the active player gets to take a tile of his/her choice. He/she can even steal one from one of the other players. Again, the back of the tile is shown so that all players get a chance at remembering how valuable (i.e. how many nectar droplets) this particular tile is.

The game ends when there are no tiles left on the mat. The players count their nectar droplets and the player with the highest number of droplets wins the game.

name: Entdecken wir Salzburg
description:
A trivia game about the Austrian federal state of Salzburg.

Game components include a board showing a map of the five districts (Gaue) of Salzburg and another of the city of Salzburg (which is its own administrative district), cards with questions from six different categories, player tokens and a six-sided colour die.

name: Sausebahn
description:
A children's game for two teams that consists of guessing and uses a wooden cablecar toy on a rope to transport tokens.

Main idea:
The children of two families visit each other using a cablecar. Each of them takes their favourite toy with them. The players try to find out which toy belongs to whom as quickly as possible.

Setup:
The players are divided into two teams. One team gets the four daughters of the Moser family, the other team the four sons of the Huber family. Each team gets 4 boy/girl tokens, 9 toy tokens, 1 player board (the team with the girls gets the boy board and vice versa). 3 of the 9 player tokens are given to the other team. Of the remaining 6, 4 are selected (without the other team knowing which ones) and placed face down on the player board. Thus each boy/girl gets assigned a toy.
Two players (one per team) stand up, each holding one end of the rope.

Gameplay:
The team playing the Huber family gets the cablecar. They put one of the boy tokens and a toy token inside the cablecar. The cablecar is attached to the rope and sent over to the other team. The team checks with the help of the player board if the boy and toy match (i.e. if it is the green boy token, the toy has to be the one that was assigned to the green boy on the board). If it is correct, the boy is put on the board and the toy is turned face up. If it is incorrect, the boy stays in the cablecar. Then the Moser family team puts a girl token and toy into the cablecar and sends the car back to the Huber family. Now the other team checks if girl and toy match. Then a new boy and toy are put into the car.
The game continues until one team has managed to guess all their child-toy combinations. This team wins the game.

name: Protour
description:
Out-golf up to 71 simultaneous opponents in this riveting game of strategy and luck. Choose between 9 and 18 holes to make the game longer or shorter (about 1-2 hours of play time). Each of the 18 holes is represented by a unique, hand-drawn map of the area, which is divided into small segments to help players gauge the approximate distance from the tee-off point to the green. Players use different colors of golf ball pawns to track their progress across each map. Just as with actual golf, players will attempt to complete the game in the fewest number of "strokes" possible. For each stroke, a player will first decide whether or not they wish to spin for a "distance bonus"--a free number of segments they are allowed to move their pawn toward the hole. This can be advantageous, but a bad spin also has the potential to land the player in a dangerous sand trap or water hazard (both of which carry a stroke penalty), so the decision should not be made lightly. After resolving or skipping this spin, the player then decides how many dice to throw, from 1 to 3, attempting to land as close to the green as possible. Each pip on the dice represents the player's ball moving forward 1 segment; therefore, if too many or too few dice are thrown, players can easily fall short of, or overshoot, their goal. Once a player lands on the green, they attempt to putt their way into the hole, which involves slightly different dice-rolling mechanics.

At the beginning of the game, each player is also given a number of Skill Cards which can be spent in various ways:
1. A Skill Card can be discarded before a roll to add an extra die. This is helpful for players who wish to have a longer drive, thereby increasing their chances of avoiding a large number of hazards or traps near the center of a map.
2. If a player does land in a hazard or trap, he or she may discard a Skill Card to ignore the stroke penalty of that hazard or trap.
3. A Skill Card may be used to change one die result on a player's putting roll, thereby refining the putting accuracy.
4. Finally, any unspent Skill Cards can be used at the end of the game to subtract a stroke from one's own score, or to add a stroke to an opponent's score.

Also includes a solo variant in which the player attempts to finish all 18 holes in under 72 strokes. This goal is then adjusted according to the player's level of success.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: North Shore-opoly
description:
Property trading game about the places, plants and animals of the North Shore of Minnesota bordering Lake Superior.
The game utilizes the watercolors of Brian Minor and Rebecca Minor to illustrate the game board, game box and deed cards.
Manufactured individually by hand in Superior, WI by Brian Minor and his family.
Playing pieces are actual pebbles collected from the shore of Lake Superior.
Each property deed has the history of the place you are purchasing. Highlighting interesting educational points of interest.
Each game is individually numbered and signed by the creator/artist Brian Minor
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Gestalt
description:
From the website:

Not only have we discovered life "out there", they've discovered us, and... they don't like us.

Terran defense systems have developed modular multi-pilot mechanical avatars whose individual assets contribute to a greater whole, combining to form custom defense solutions as Earth (and its colonies) prepare to defend themselves from alien forces. These avatars are collectively known as "The Gestalt"

Play cooperatively or competitively as you develop individual Gestalt Components, and try to build the defenders needed to protect your colony. Unlock available technology in the face of impending danger. Stave off menacing alien threats!

Gestalt is a worker placement game, where players (cooperatively or competitively) assign workers to tasks to build Gestalt Mechs. Each piece of the mech provides a number of resources or attributes. Once a mech is ready, you assign those mechs to face an incoming threat. The resources provided by the components is spent, or lost, and some parts will need to be replaced before the next battle. Undefeated threats can destroy parts of the board, cutting you off from valuable resources, so build quickly!
publishers: Dragon Pro Studios, The Game Crafter, LLC

name: Superman
description:
A game for two to five players. There are 36 cards in the pack. The object of the game is to get rid of all your cards by playing one at a time. When play has been completed, the cards held in the players’ hands count against them. The lowest score wins.

Select a dealer. Shuffle the cards and deal five, one at a time, face downwards to each player. If there are two players, deal seven at a time. Place the remaining cards face down on the table in front of the players. Turn the top card face up, next to the pile. This is the card on to which other cards will be played. If this card is a Superman card, replace it in the middle of the pile and turn over another.

The person on the dealer's left commences by playing face up on the up turned card, one that matches it. He may play either one of the same number or of the same background colour. For instance, if the first card is a number three Super Boy, yellow, he may play any yellow card or any number three card regardless of colour. All Superman cards ere wild and can be played when a player wishes. After playing a Superman card, the player may play next whatever card he wishes. Play continues in a clockwise fashion.

A player who cannot make a match or play a Superman card. must draw from the pile and does not play that turn. When the centre pile is exhausted, a player passes if he cannot play.

The game is over when either one of the players is out of cards or when nobody can play. Players then total their points, counting each card at face value except the Superman cards which count 25. The game may be continued for a series of runs until one player reaches an agreed number of points, say 100. The lowest scorer then wins.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Comic Book / Strip

name: Hunt the Hunny
description:
An action version of games like Snap. There are 36 cards.

Deal out all the cards which players stack in a pile in front of them (without looking at them). Starting with the player left of the dealer, a player turns over the top card in his pile and puts it the centre of the table. Thus, the game progresses. Shouls one of the four Hunny cards be revealed, all the players must race to be the first to touch the card. The fastest player gets all the cards in the centre of the table which go face-down on the bottom of his stack. It is suggested that if at all possible, a referee should be on hand to settle disputes over who was the quickest. If you run out of cards you may still join in the race for the next Hunny card but should you be not the quickest, you are out of the game. In effect, you get a second chance to stay in the game.

The winner is the player who collects all the cards.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Children's Game, Novel-based

name: Stack-o-Saurus Card Game
description:
From the publisher:
Get your dino game on with Stack-o-Saurus: a card game that's not only a cinch to learn but that's different every time you play! Be the first to crack the code of stacking dinosaurs...the winner is the first player to complete a Dino Tower. However, players need to watch out for T-Rex since he can topple your tower in no time!

48 jumbo cards.

name: Ambassador: England
description:
Trivia and chance game! Play as an ambassador of an European country and answer questions correctly to win the appreciation of the English Ambassador. The game is available as open source and can be modified to your discretion.

It is a similar take on trivial pursuit, where one must roll the dice and then move to a spot where you can pick a question card and answer it. Correctly answering it, earns you a token and you turn in points for tokens at the English Ambassador square, at the centre of the board. You win be either being ahead by 5 points or having the most points after answering all questions. Tokens do not count as points. If there is a tie in points at the end of the game, then a random question card will be drawn and the best with the fastest correct answer, wins. Otherwise, another question card will be drawn until there is a winner. Only the players in a tie are eligible to answer the question.

name: TrucKing
description:
Players travel across a map of 24 North American cities connected by highways in a race to deliver goods to every city before his/her opponents.

Every city has a limited supply of one type of six unique goods, but that same city demands two others-and the two goods change with every delivery. Players earn money for delivering the requested goods, but the journey isn't without costs, which must be effectively managed to save up for truck upgrades which allow you to transport more goods. The more cities you visit, the more bonus points you earn at game's end. There's also an additional bonus for being the first to visit a city. Six of the cities are in Canada, which presents its own unique challenge as carrying goods across the border requires paying a tariff. Each city, one by one, is randomly designated as a bonus city during the game, earning the first delivery driver to reach that city a bonus payout.

Who will manage their deliveries most efficiently and score the victory? Buckle up and hit the road!

name: Stone's Throw
description: Players roll 9 dice, attempting to roll combinations (e.g., seven 5s). Successful completion of combinations earns the right to reroll dice on future turns to complete harder combinations. Certain combinations also award gems that are collected and later sold for victory points. The value of the gems decrease as the game goes on. Additional bonuses are won for being the first to sell sets of gems-larger sets earn more victory points.

name: Inside Golf
description:
Players chose a club and then spin the wheel to determine the outcome of each shot. Markers are used to show ball position on the game board. Players keep track of number of strokes to complete each hole on a scorecard. Player with the lowest total score at the end of 9 holes is declared the winner.

Endorsement and photos of Sam Snead.

name: Pulverfass
description:
A balancing/stacking dexterity game with a timing element.

Players take turns trying to stack little plastic barrels and planks onto a platform. The platform has a timer built in that is turned on at the beginning of each turn and switched off at the end of turn. The platform turns/wobbles. If barrels fall down, the active player has to stack all the barrels in other players' colours before he/she is allowed to use the off-switch. If the time runs out, the platform tilts, all barrels tumble down and the game is over. The player who has the fewest barrels left wins the game.

The level of difficulty can be adjusted with a switch. A solo variant exists in which the player tries to beat either a time record or how many barrels they manage to stack.

name: Murli Katzensprung
description:
An educational game that aims at teaching kids about environmental issues.

The board shows a rain forest, the sea, a mountain forest, farmland and a garden. Die rolls determine how far a player can move on the board. The aim of the game is to collect as many oxygen chips as possible. This is done by landing on action spaces, drawing an action card and successfully completing the action/answering the question. There are also spaces which mean that the players get to listen to one of the 10 songs from the CD that is included. The player with the most chips wins the game.

name: 2 WAY ボードゲーム 逃走中 ＆ 戦闘中
description:
Combining two games into one box on a reversible game board, 2 WAY Board Game Tousouchuu & Sentouchuu brings the excitement of the popular Japanese TV game shows to your table.

In Tousouchuu: run for money players must try to avoid being caught by the ultra-fast Hunters while earning more money every second they are in the game. If a Hunter should spot one of the players, the chase is on! Fail to escape and you are eliminated from the game... and you walk away empty handed! To make matters more interesting, Missions will be sent to the players that require them to take risks if they wish to succeed. Participating in the Missions is completely optional but be warned: should the players fail a Mission, they must suffer the consequences... usually in the form of more Hunters entering the game. Whoever survives until the end receives the full amount of money for the game!

On the other hand, in Sentouchuu: battle for money the hunted become the hunters! In this game, players are after each other. Armed with Battle Balls, they compete in a game of high-stakes dodgeball. Eliminate another player and you take all their money. A player can try to save their money until the end, hoping they can outwit and outlast the other players. Or they can spend the cash to buy more effective weapons including the powerful Shinobi, a ninja that fights alongside the player! In this game, the last man standing takes all!
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game

name: Imperial Wars: Colonial Warfare Rules 1860-1900
description:
From the Introduction

The years from 1860-1900 saw vast areas of the world under the domination of the British flag. Victoria's armies had fought campaigns as far afield as China, Afghanistan, India and the Continent of Africa, occasionally suffering defeat but never to be vanquished.

Imperial Wars 1860-1900 Wargame Rules hope to capture some of the flavour of the period and provide the playability we all seek.

The rules include army lists for some of the period's main protagonists, and a points system to allow for ahistorical battles to be fought between roughly equivalent forces.

Like many miniature rule sets, the designer has defined both the ground scale (and consequently, the figure basing parameters):

Ground Scale:
25mm - 2cm = 10 yds
15mm - 1cm = 10 yds

The turn sequence calls for simultaneous movement and is defined as follows:

1. Declare charges and test for them
2. Carry out movement simultaneously
3. Adjudicate fire
4. Test for morale caused by firing
5. Adjudicate melees
6. Carry out all other morale tests

name: Fall of Eagles: Late 19th Century Warfare Rules
description:
From the Introduction

Fall of Eagles is to some extent a companion to our Imperial Wars sets, which enable players to recreate colonial actions in the nineteenth century. Fall of Eagles shifts the scene from Queen Victoria's little wars to the major conflicts in Europe itself. The rules are designed to allow wargamers to taste the flavour of formal warfare in the nineteenth century. It is a period which saw great changes in both the political make-up of Europe and the technology of warfare.

The designer has defined both the ground scale (and consequently, the figure basing parameters):

Figure Scale: 1 figure = 50 men (infantry and cavalry)
Ground Scale: 1cm = 20 yds

The rules include army lists for the period's major powers, as well as a points system to allow for ahistorical battles to be fought between roughly equivalent forces.

name: Ticketack
description:
A children's game focusing on the clock.

The little cuckoo that comes out of the clock to announce the hours is very busy. Can you help him to organise his activities so that he can call out the hours on time?

Setup: The 12 clock counters (one for each hour) are turned face down and shuffled. Players take turns turning them face up and placing them on the board in clockwise order. The clock hand is placed in the center of the board. The wooden cuckoo is placed on the red twelve. The 24 cards are distributed evenly among the players. They show what the cuckoo is doing (watching TV, going for a hike etc.) and how long it takes him (1-4 hours).

Game play: The starting player spins the clock's hand. The hand shows the time at which the cuckoo has to be back to call out the hour. Then the active player puts a card next to the board and moves the cuckoo 1-4 spaces, depending on the duration that the card states. If the cuckoo lands on a space before the time indicated by the clock's hand, the cuckoo is too early. He's got time for another activity and it is the next player's turn now. If the cuckoo lands on space indicated by the clock's hand, he is just on time. As a reward, the player may place another card of his/her choice on the stack next to the board. If the cuckoo lands after the time indicated by the hand, it means he is late. As a penalty, the player has to take back his/her card and draws an additional card from the pile.

The player who manages to get rid of his/her cards first wins the game.

A second variant listed in the instructions consists of players taking turns telling what the cuckoo is doing when. e.g. player 1 says "At seven o'clock the cuckoo gets out of bed." Then the clock's hand is advanced one hour and the next player says what the cuckoo is doing at eight o'clock. (This is a speaking activity rather than a game; there is no winning condition.)

name: Kopf an Kopf
description:
A card game collection for children that contains 3 different little games/activities that are all played with the same set of cards.

The cards are printed on both sides - orange on one, purple on the other. The orange side usually shows two animal heads (sometimes more), the purple side always six animal heads.

The first game is a simple picture dominoes variant. Players put their cards next to one with a matching animal head.

The main game, "Schnabel und Schnauze" is played using the purple side of the cards. Each player draws three cards. A starting card is placed and then players take turns. On your turn, you can either draw a card (hand limit is 4), add a card (cards are all placed in longitudinal direction) next to another so that a row of identical animal heads results, or put a card ON another without completely covering it. Players earn points for making rows of the same animal longer. The player with the most points wins the game.

The third variant is "Zoo-M", in which the purple side of the cards is used in a puzzle of 3x4, 4x5 or 6x6 cards. At the edges, the animals have to match.

Components:
- 36 cards, printed on both sides
- 2 cards that contain the instructions
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Puzzle

name: Bibelthriller
description:
A Werewolf/Mafia type game with a Christian theme.

In Jerusalem the population, consisting of Israelites, Romans and characters from the Bible are trying to defend themselves against a group of fanatics trying to seize power.
Each player is randomly and secretly assigned a role card. Players try to keep their identities secret, which leads to everyone becoming suspicious of being a fanatic. The population can only be kept safe if the fanatics can be found out and evicted from the city as soon as possible.

The game is played in alternating rounds of night (when the fanatics decide on a victim to murder) and day (when court hearings and evictions take place). Each fraction (Israelites and Romans versus fanatics) tries to eliminate the other. Once all the night activities have taken place, the player whose character has been killed that night is eliminated from the game. The remaining players decide on a player they want to evict from the city. That player is eliminated from the game as well. The game is played until only one fraction is left, which then wins the game.

The game contains 32 cards. Among the role cards are characters from the Bible with special skills: Jesus can convert a fanatic if he identifies him/her correctly. Maria can protect a person against the fanatics. The necromancer can bring back a dead character by taking over his/her identity.
categories: Bluffing, Deduction, Murder/Mystery, Negotiation, Party Game, Religious
mechanics: Role Playing, Variable Player Powers, Voting

name: Mighty Morphin Power Rangers Villain Strike Game
description:
The Power Rangers battle the evil Lord Zedd to save their beloved Angel Grove from being destroyed by Lord Zedd’s evil Space Aliens! Can you stop him?

Players choose to defend the city Angel Grove playing as the Power Rangers or as the evil Lord Zedd and his evil Space Aliens as they battle against each other or as a team! Each player has matching pairs of Character Tokens and three Safety Tokens (which can be used to hide your Character Token from the other player’s view). In addition to these tokens are the Lose a Turn Tokens; players will lose a turn if they knock down these tokens. Each player has two tokens that can make the other player lose a turn.

Game play consists of players sitting 5ft apart from one another and taking turns firing their Battle Weapon. Players try to knock down matching character pairs that are arranged strategically behind the 5ft mark. The first player or team to knock down at least three matching Character Token pairs wins!

Each player gets their evil or good side (Lord Zedd or Power Rangers) Character Tokens and places them strategically arranged behind the 5ft mark. Each Character Token has an individual features a different Power Ranger or the evil Lord Zedd and his evil Space Aliens on them.

name: Quick and Dirty Space Combat Game
description:
A quick and dirty space combat game.
Finished but in Alpha.

QDSCG uses basic ideas and concepts, with generalized fire power, but there is still the interplay of missiles, fighters, and direct combat. Abstraction is the key, but the system has the ability to open up to allow easy rule changes.

Using simple rules, no tables, no off board record keeping, the games is designed to allow masses space combat of fleet scale engagements take place with in a short play time of 1-2 hours. Larger engagements between teams could easily be taught and played at a convention with a simple cheat sheet keeping track of all rules.

name: Wild Cards: Backyard Birds
description:
This card game + book set features songbirds, woodpeckers, hummingbirds, birds that are tricksters, little chirpers and more. Learn about each bird’s personality and how to identify them.
Learn about birds as you play three favorite card games: Memory, Old Maid, and Go Fish. Created in association with the Cornell Lab of Ornithology, and filled with wonderful images from leading wildlife photographers.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Educational

name: Mork from Ork Name Game
description:
Game published in the UK Issue 34 of Cracked Magazine.

The board is a deceasing circle track ultimately leading to the middle of the board. Movement is by the roll of one die. The object is to collect letter cards that spell out MORK FROM ORK. The first one to do so, wins. If you get to the centre without a complete sewt, you must discard two letters and go back to the start to try again.

In the grand tradition of magazine games, all the cards have to be cut out before play can begin.
categories: Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Word Game

name: Paperclip Railways: Stupid City
description:
Bonus station card. Base game has three 'placeholder' station cards that can be cashed in for a promo of choice 'from the box'.

From the card:
"Game End: Ignore your final score; you finish in 2nd place."
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Tile Placement

name: Ace Quiz: Pop Music
description:
More interesting Quiz card game than usual. As you play, there is a code to take you to the next card, and so on until you have eight cards all connected. However, if you have been 100% correct you will see that the last code is the code for your first card. If it isn't then you must work out where you must have given a wrong answer or more wrong answers if 2 or more cards are incorrectly answered.

First player to get a correct set of eight cards, wins.

name: Treasure Island
description:
Book that appeared in the Jolly Gnomes Annual in 1952.

It is a familiar roll and move game, in the tradition of Goose-type games. Each player has to get from their boat (space 1) and follow the track to the Hidden Treasure (Space 100).

It is livened up by quite a nuimber of side tracks (which are mostly bad). Other than that, move according to your die roll and obey instructions when you land on the special spaces. First to reach the Hidden Treasure, wins.

name: Climbing the Greasy Poles
description:
A game that appeared in the Jolly Gnomes Annual in 1951.

The board features 4 poles, with 15 spaces from bottom to top. Each player uses a separate pole. Movement is by a die. Nearly every space on the pole has instructions, sometimes good, sometimes bad. You must obey the instructions, of course.

When a player reaches the top (by exact throw of course, in games of this vintage), wins the round. Everyone starts at the bottom and play again proceeds as above. The first player to win ten rounds, wins.

name: Reel In
description:
The Fish is on the line & The Fisher is hungry. Make your move to gain freedom or your dinner.

Available on twitchSKETCH.ca, players can download this 2 player Print & Play fishing game. Play as either the Fish or the Fisher and play Direction cards against your opponent.

Players reveal their Direction at the same time. As the Fish you'll swim in a matching direction keep strength and swim to freedom. As the Fisher you'll be pulling the line in the opposite direction to try and snag the fish, pulling it close until you catch the other player. Read your opponent and make the right move.

If players don't get a win scenario, break into Panic Play and change the result as fast as you can.

The key feature in this game is it's illustrated score tracker. As players win they move the Fish closer to freedom or closer to the Fisher.

With only a few sheets, this is a fast game to set up and a fast game to play multiple times.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Animals, Bluffing, Card Game, Children's Game, Humor, Print & Play
mechanics: Pattern Building, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection, Storytelling, Trick-taking

name: Andromeda traders
description:
In Andromeda Traders you are a captain in charge of your own space ship. You can choose to be a pirate, a smuggler or an honest trader. Choose you trade route, customize your crew, buy black market goods or trade in commodities. Or simply be a raider preying on the weak.

Each player starts with a Captain, a ship and few resources. By flying from planet to planet you will build up your cash reserves by buying and selling goods or by picking up fee paying passengers. For the desperate you can even deal in illegal goods or maybe hire marines to raid other traders cargo holds. To travel further and faster you can also hire on board extra crew- helpful when outrunning nefarious traders who have eyes on your cargo.

Seek fortune on the trading lanes and be the richest person in the Galaxy!

name: Savage Wars of Peace: Rules for Gaming in the Victorian Era
description:
From the Introduction

Savage Wars of Peace is a set of rules for gaming the colonial wars of the Victorian Era. This rules set provides a quick playing yet historically accurate simulation for this exciting period. These rules are primarily intended to recreate the major battles at the height of the Colonial period, 1878-1901.

This is not a set of skirmish rules. Units are battalions or their native equivalents. After becoming familiar with the rules, players should be able to recreate some of the great battles of colonial campaigns such as Ulundi, Abu Klea, Kandahar and the relief of Peking. With a little experience, each player should be able to comfortably handle a brigade sized unit of 3,000 scale men.

The rules are primarily intended for use with 15mm scale military miniatures. 20mm and 25mm figures use a slightly different figure scale and mounting arrangement, but the time and ground scales remain the same (1 turn = 5 minutes, and 1" = 20 yds). The game uses both average dice and 20 sided (percentile) dice to resolve morale and combat situations.

The expanded edition includes information and data to play the campaigns in the following colonial wars:


Indian Mutiny
Second Afghan War
Zulu War
Egyptian Rebellion
French conquest of Tonkin
Mahdist Uprising
French campaign in Dahomey
Reconquest of the Sudan
Great Pathan Revolt
Boer Wars
Boxer Rebellion
French conquest of Morocco
publishers: 19th Century Miniatures, Inc., Poor Beggars in Red Games

name: T-Rex World: Tal der Gefahren
description:
A dinosaur-themed roll-and-move travel game for children. It comes in a tin box and uses magnetic player pieces.

The board (printed inside the tin box) shows a racing track consisting of 30 spaces. 8 of them are special spaces (showing the numbers +1, -1, +2, +3 or a T-rex head). One space is both the starting and finish space. At the side of the box, there is a strength indicator for each dinosaur. It is set to 1 at the start of the game and adjusted when that player's dinosaur token lands on one of the special fields with numbers.
Players take turns rolling a standard six-sided number die. The active player moves his/her dinosaur token the number of spaces corresponding to the die roll. If the token lands on a special field with a number, that player's dinosaur gains or loses strength accordingly. If a player lands on one of the two battle spaces (= spaces with the T-rex head symbol), he/she can challenge another player that is ahead of him/her. Both players roll the die and add their dino's current strength to the result. If the challenging dino wins the battle (die roll plus strength > that of the defending dino), the two tokens swap places. The challenger is now ahead.

The player whose dino reaches the finish space first wins the game.

name: YeeHawd
description:
The fun family game about Holy War and the End of the World.

Yeehawd! is a satirical tabletop game designed for three to six players where you take on the role of a Prophet preparing for the End Of The World.

The purpose of the game is to collect as many followers to your faith as possible before Armageddon to secure your place in the Afterlife.

Every game is divided into seven chapters, in which the Prophets use their spiritual connection, as shown by their available Mana, to play Verse cards. A new chapter card is drawn and resolved at the start of each new round.

There are four different types of Verse cards.
Acts of God: Cards that negatively affect the other players
Miracles: Cards that affect you in a positive way
Disbelief: Cards that cancel or in other ways affect Miracle or Faith cards
Faith: Cards that cancel or in other ways affect Acts of God or Disbelief cards

At the end of the game the Prophet with the most followers wins the game, and the rest of you get a ticket to that hot fiery place downstairs. However, should two or more prophets be tied to win, they are all annihilated in a furious Holy War and the next prophet in line wins the game. A game usually takes anything from 30 minutes to an hour depending on how many players you have.
mechanics: Action Points, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Open Drafting, Variable Player Powers

name: Victoria's Battles Scenario Book One: Egypt and the Sudan 1881-1898
description:
From the Introduction

This is the first of three scenario books that will provide both historical and fictional based gaming scenarios set during the period of 19th Century British Colonial conflict. The book contains 7 scenarios.

Each scenario has been well play-tested. Each will provide the basis for an exciting wargaming experience using the Victoria's Battles rule system. Not all of the scenarios are perfectly balanced and this is intentional as engagements were often less balanced affairs. While it may be difficult to actually win the scenario outright, the tactical challenges make for exciting games.

name: Victoria's Battles Book Two: The Zulu War 1879
description:
From the Introduction

Between 1837 and 1901, Great Britain found itself in a virtual state of constant warfare. Military expeditions undertaken to protect and expand the Empire became an accepted facet of Victorian life. When compared to great military encounters such as the Seven Years War, the Napoleonic Wars, and the unprecedented World Wars of the Twentieth Century, Britain's colonial wars were small affairs. Yet each produced a more prominent and stronger Empire. The entire period is a portrait of British martial zeal.

This is a set of highly playable rules that is well thought out and well tested The rules allow for the playing of battles covering Britain's 1879 Zulu War. Also included are one introductory scenario and three historically based scenarios.

This set of rules is the second in a series of rule sets covering the 19th Century British Colonial Experience.

The rules are designed to play any size action using figure scales between 15mm and 25/30mm, Modifications for the use of smaller scle figures is easy. We recommend the mounting of of multiple smaller figures on the same size bases given for 15mm figures. The unit scale is variable. The rules allow for a flexible playing scale that can be used to play small patrol level games up to the largest battle of the period, Omdurman.

name: Victoria's Battles Book III: The Northwest Frontier
description:
From the Introduction

Between 1837 and 1901, Great Britain found itself in a virtual state of constant warfare. Military expeditions undertaken to protect and expand the Empire became an accepted facet of Victorian life. When compared to great military encounters such as the Seven Years War, the Napoleonic Wars, and the unprecedented World Wars of the Twentieth Century, Britain's colonial wars were small affairs. Yet each produced a more prominent and stronger Empire. The entire period is a portrait of British martial zeal.

This is a set of highly playable rules that is well thought out and well tested The rules allow for the playing of battles covering Britain's conflicts along India's North West Frontier. The rules cover the conflict from the 1830's through to the end of the century. Also included are one introductory scenario and three historically based scenarios.

This set of rules is the third in a series of rule sets covering the 19th Century British Colonial experience.

The rules are designed to play any size action using figure scales between 15mm and 25/30mm, Modifications for the use of smaller scle figures is easy. We recommend the mounting of of multiple smaller figures on the same size bases given for 15mm figures. The unit scale is variable. The rules allow for a flexible playing scale that can be used to play small patrol level games up to the largest battle of the period, Omdurman.

name: The 19th Hole
description:
This is a combination board game/drinking game. The players take turns rolling the die, mvoing their game piece the number shown then follow the instructions on the square they land on - if any. For example, if the player lands on a hazard, he must drink a shot. The winner of the game is the first one to reach the "hole" by the exact roll of the die or drink shots until the player does.

The contents of the shots are determined by the players before the game; but may be changed during game play if all players are in agreement.

Contents:
Frosted glass game board
6 game pieces
6 shot glasses
1 die

name: Sink the Biz
description:
Sink the Biz (originally "Sink the Bismark") is a dexterity game traditionally played at Nick's English Hut in Bloomington, IN.

The game is played using a metal bucket filled with beer, with a small weighted juice glass (the "Biz") floating in it. The bucket is placed in the middle of the table, within easy reach of all players. Each player has a glass filled with the same type beer that is in the bucket. Players take turns pouring small amounts of their beer inside the floating glass. Usually players agree on a minimum height from which the beer must be poured into the Biz. Also, it is generally acknowledged that just a drop or two of beer are not enough to satisfy one's turn requirement. In case of any ambiguity in this sense, all the other players vote to decide whether or not a pour was enough. If it is decided that the active player did not pour the minimum amount, the active player must pour again before his turn is over.

The player who sinks the Biz must recover it from the bucket and drink all of its content. After that, the Biz is placed back in the bucket, players' glasses are refilled, and the process is repeated. Players may drop out of the game at any time. The game is over when only one player remains in the game. That player is the winner.

The game allows for limited strategic decisions. The main strategy is to fill the Biz as much as possible during one's turn, to make it more likely for the next player to sink the Biz. This is, however, a calculated risk, as the player attempting this technique may end up pouring too much beer and sinking the Biz as a result.

name: A Bit of Banter Junior
description:
By encouraging children to share their dreams, thoughts, fears and aspirations in a fun and non-threatening way, A Bit of Banter Jr. is a game where anyone can become the "Best Banterer". The goal is to collect the most gemstones and become “Best Banterer”.

Once everyone (including the first player) has answered, the first player chooses a gemstone and awards it to the person whose answer he/she like best* (for whatever reason – that’s the fun part!). Players can (and should!) ask each other to elaborate on the answers, especially if the answers are too short! Players can skip a turn but by doing so they miss a chance to win a gemstone. The game ends when players simply agree to stop playing or when all gemstones have been distributed.

The option "When you were my age..." allows children to get to know their parents and grand-parents better and involves adults in the game!

name: Happy Spider
description:
User description

A take-that simultaneous action selection game. On the game board, berries are placed in 4 different locations, and the goal of the game is to collect them. Each player has a selection of 6 roles, one for each of the locations on the board (with some twists to them, and of which one blocks the others), one that steals from the others, and a last one who simply gets berries. Roles are chosen simultaneously; players who are blocked cannot collect berries this round. Players who choose the same location to collect from, share the berries from that locations. Game goes on until someone has 21 berries.

name: TroelieWoelies: zoek je plaatjes
description: All players search for a group of 3 images as pictured on the card. The player who finds the combination first places one of his marbles between the images. and wins the card. when all marbles are placed, the player who collected most cards wins the game.

name: Freddy the Fox
description:
A card game like Authors, Quartetts or Happy Families but with some novel touches.

The cards, which are beautifull illustrated, feature sets of four cards. There are 45 cards in total, and the sets are numbered 1 to 4. There is also a Freddy the Fox card which should be given to another player during play (if you get the chance). The collecting of sets is traditional: Ask for a card from a set that you already have one card in. If the player askled has one, he hands it over. If he doesn't then he can call "Exchange" and the asker and asked choose one card to give to the other (face-down of course). This is the only way to get rid of useless cards from your point of view and, of course, to get rid of Freddy if you happen to hold it.

There are 12 other cards called Trophy cards. They have a fold in the centre and can be stood up like an arch (a very nice touch). When you lay down a completed set, you take the trophy card that relates to it. The Trophy cards all have a points value, some sets worth more than others.

When all the sets have been found, each player adds up their Trophy card scores, but getting -50 to the holder of Freddy the Fox at the end. The first player to score 250 or more, wins. This may take several games to achieve.

name: Happy Feet Two: Freezing Frenzy Game
description:
