They are Communications, Munitions, Airport, Presidential Palace. The game proceeds by each player in their turn playing a road taking tile to move them forward. You have farther to go than the Dictator who advances automatically at the end of each turn. The only way to take an Objective is to coordinate your assault as you advance block by hard won block But only one of you can win each round. When is the timing right for striking out on your own?

Like the game Risk boiled down to its most excruciating 20 minutes.

name: The Greatest Show on Earth
description:
Roll and move children's game with circus theme. The players should roll the dice and go around the circle, pick cards and follow the instructions on them. The winner is the first player, who reach finish line by exact count.
The paper gameboard has a great circus tent scene. There are 72 original paper cards that players pick to navigate their routes and four colored wooden place markers.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: World-O
description:
Girl Scouts & Guides game "WORLD-O, ohé! le monde". "A game on the world association of girl guides and girl scouts".
Players taking question cards and try to answer questions (answer cards shows the right answer) about scouting. The player at the end (then no more question cards left) with the most amount of answered questions win the game.

name: The Robust Game of Robin Hood
description:
Simple spin and move game similar to many others of the times with Robin Hood theme. Players spin and move exact amount, take a direction card and follow the instructions. The first who cross finish line wins the game.
There are four characters: Robin Hood (green), Will Scarlet (red), Friar Tuck (black) and Sheriff of Nottingham (yellow).

name: BattleGroup
description:
The third volume in the HorizonWars Trilogy, following MechaWar and AirFrame, BattleGroup introduces the rest of the combined arms force to the game.

BattleGroup is a hard science fiction battle game for actions from platoon to battalion level that captures the tactical dynamic of the all-arms force. Tanks, artillery and infantry must fight as a cohesive whole under the command of a single headquarters, but every army has its own style and emphasis - how will you lead?

Players assemble their forces from a menu of options based on their choice of Command Headquarters. Battles are scenario-based in which each player must fight for competing priorities, with each taking their turn to activate a single element - but your opponent's forces can react to the actions of your own. As elements take damage, their ability to fight on is gradually eroded or, if they suffer a critical hit, they may be destroyed entirely! Should you put your injured soldiers into cover where they can patch up their injured and call up reinforcements? Or should you press on for a vital objective?

The game is compatible with the other two volumes of HorizonWars, so you can add mighty mech battlesuits to your forces for additional punch and real sci-fi flavour, and dispatch squadrons of aircraft to lay down close support alongside your advancing troops.

The design draws deeply upon the experiences of the author, a former officer in the British Army, to deliver a high-quality tactical experience with a powerfully realistic feel, whilst still giving a play experience that can be completed in under an hour.

Key features:

Miniatures wargame of modern/science fiction combat
Integrated turn sequence
Action-based turns
d12-based dice pool for "one roll" shooting actions
Customizable statlines
Compatible with MechaWar and AirFrame from One Pound Wargames
Designed for use with any range of modern or science fiction miniatures in scales from 1/805 (2mm) to 1/161 (10mm)
Includes advanced rules and three starting scenarios

name: The Busy World of Richard Scarry: Busiest Shopping Day Ever Game
description:
Match the colors and be the first busy shopper to collect everything on your shopping list!

Each player selects a shopping list and a shopper playing piece. 24 cardboard grocery item tokens are placed on their matching spaces on the board.

On each turn, the player spins the spinner and moves his shopper to the next matching colored space on the gameboard path. If the player lands on a space next to an item on his shopping list, he takes that item from the gameboard and puts it on his shopping list card. Bonus moves include a Free Coupon space and spinning on Bananas Gorilla or Sergeant Murphy.

The first player to get to the checkout space with all the items on his list is the winner.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Zwergen-Schatz
description:
Theme
Players try to win most of the dwarves' treasure.

Goal
Collect as many plastic chips ("gold coins") as possible.

Game play
The board shows one central circle and 9 circles arranged around it. Each circle has a number from 2 to 11 printed at the center, and a number of small markings corresponding to that number around it. A plastic pot filled with plastic chips is placed on the central circle.
Players take turns rolling the two six-sided dice. The result of a roll is added up and a chip is placed on one of the markings on the corresponding circle (e. g. if you roll a 4 and a 5, you put a chip on one of the markings on circle 9).
If you roll a 12, you put a chip on a circle of your choice.
When all markings on one circle have been filled and that number is rolled again, the player wins the chips from that circle.

The game ends when a player has collected 20 chips or when there are no chips left in the pot. The player who has collected the most chips wins the game.

name: Rhyme Time
description:
A Game of Rhyming and Poetry based on the books of Dr. Seuss.

Players roll one die and move a communal pawn around the game board. When a player lands the mover on a "Rhyme" or "Poem" space, he draws a "Rhyme" or "Poem" card and completes the actions shown on the card. The card actions include word play activities like: Name four words that rhyme with "cat"; Make up a four-line poem about the sea.

If a player completes an action correctly, he moves his colored Hat marker a certain number of spaces towards the multi-colored Hat in the center, then back out again towards his own colored Hat space. The first player to return his Hat to its starting space wins.

name: Timeline 300
description:
From Publisher's Introduction:
"Timeline 300 is a tabletop wargame, designed to be played between two or more players, that uses collectable miniatures which are intended to be built, painted, and personalised by each player so that she can construct a personal army of her (or perhaps, his) very own. Your tactical skill, and a random factor determined by the roll of dice, shall decide who wins your own “wars that never were”.

The game depicts a Martian invasion of earth during steam technology era. Players generate resources from specific units (such as mining units) each turn that can be used to 'purchase' combat units for use in the battle portion of the game. It simulates the type of action found in many real-time-strategy (RTS) games where resources and facilities help guide what type of forces each player can bring to bear.

name: Gemstone Island
description:
The King of Gemstone Island does not have an heir to the throne. Thus, he has set up a competition to determine who is worthy of being next in line as King or Queen.

To win this competition and thus become next in line to rule the island, you must be the first player to successfully bury a complete collection of gemstones. As you attempt to complete your mission, any of the following may happen: a hole in your sack, an earthquake, someone switching sacks with you (without your permission, of course), someone bumping into you and then picking up the gems you drop, or even another player digging up all that treasure you worked so hard to bury!

name: Great Minds Think
description:
Great minds think ... alike? outside the box?
Can you think as a group or by yourself? Can you confound the group into choosing something different?

This is a light-hearted fun little party game. Players are trying to guess what the majority of the group will think and choose that answer, or choose something that others will not choose. Whomever has the most points over several rounds is the winner.

On a round the active player:
- selects one of their cards and reveals it to the group
(the cards have several options listed e.g. cat, mouse, cheese)
- forms a phrase/sentence/question about that card
- reveals the "goal" card (which indicates "alike" or "outside of the box")

Players then try to select the best answer according to the "Group Goal" card. If "alike" is revealed, they are trying to be in the group with the majority of guesses, if "outside of the box" is revealed, they are trying to not be in the group with the majority of guesses.

The inspiration of this game was to make a silly little fun filler, that was portable that would provide lots of laughter, while allowing players to come up with creative statements of their own.

name: Viaje al Centro de la Tierra
description:
Game for two to four players, inspired by the novel by Jules Verne.
Players travel to the center of the earth, should get the materials needed to make progress and be the first out of the volcano Stromboli.
Its components are:
Board, 12 counters, dice, 57 cards (possibly missing a few).


Juego de dos a cuatro jugadores,inspirado en la novela de Julio Verne.
Los jugadores viajan al centro de la tierra, deben conseguir los materiales necesarios para avanzar y ser los primeros en salir por el volcan Stromboli.
Sus componentes son:
Tablero, 12 fichas,dado, 57 cartas (posiblemente faltan algunas).

name: Consumers Power Play
description:
A educational/trivia game about electrical power.

Pull a power card and answer a question determined by the color of the card. Answer correctly and move 1 to 3 spaces on the board. Follow directions on board space if any (move forward/back). Answer incorrectly and loose turn.

Winner is first person to land on or pass their starting space.

name: Game of Familiar Quotations
description:
Similar to the game Authors, each card features 5 quotations from a single author. Quotations are read until someone guesses the author correctly.

From the New-York Times of August 22, 1863:
"Mr. John H. Tingley, of No. 152 Fulton-street, advertises a new game for the social circle, called the "Game of Familiar Quotations." It affords a very pleasant way of becoming acquainted with the beauties of Shakespeare, Cowper, Colley Cibber, Young, Coleridge and others, whose writings add beauty to the English classics."

name: Rise of the Rock Star
description:
Rise of the Rock Star is a board game where players use 2 decks of combo-making cards and roll dice in a race around the unique multi-level board, rising in notoriety to become a Rock and Roll Legend. Players gain Fame Points to Level Up and to ultimately win the game. The variety of methods that players can use to gain Fame Points creates automatic momentum allowing players to focus on which strategy is best for each game.

Rise of the Rock Star is a game for 2-4 players ages 13+. Most versions of the game can be played in around 45 minutes, and several included alternate play methods allow game to increase and decrease in strategic complexity and length of play, making the game fun, customizable, and playable again and again.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Roll / Spin and Move, Variable Player Powers

name: Wer ist Walli?
description:
The twelve wooden animals are placed in the center.
Question card is drawn and question is asked about one of the 12 animals. Child who first know the answer takes the animal.
If all animals is taken the player with the most animals is the winner.

Many other game-variants included.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Trivia

name: FlashNics
description:
FlashNics is a uniquely crafted deck of cards that can be used for serious and casual gaming, as well as educational purposes. Players will also be able to design their own "game sanctioned" cards at the FlashNics.com website.

FlashNics allows you to recruit mercenaries from across the galaxy to battle for you against other competing entities. Mercenaries will compete against one another in one of four arenas that appeal to differing skill-sets. Winning across all four arenas and the ability to secure them (or winning in extreme fashion) is necessary to defeat your opponents.

Game Play :

One of four starting arenas is chosen. Each player starts with 6 mercenary cards (not shared) drawn randomly from the game deck. The first player chooses a card combination he/she will use to attempt to defend the arena depending on the attributes of the mercenary. The second player responds with a valid card combination (depending on the first combinations, others aren't allowed). Play then resumes until one player submits the round.

The player that wins the round can then decide to defend an arena with the mercenary used in the winning combination, or can choose to run protection with the mercenary. Each player then draws up to 6 cards again.

Hand maintenance is critical, as values accumulated depend on the strength of the victorious card (the least powerful cards score higher) and cards strength in each of the 4 arenas varies. Once the original deck is near depletion, being aware of cards still in play is a valuable tactic. Various modifier and action cards can also modify gameplay.

40 points are necessary to win the game (the sum of the mercenary protection values; double the value of this number if all four arenas are defended). Advanced players can create exclusive mercenaries with unique actions at http://FlashNics.com and use them directly in gameplay.

name: KIBIK
description: Two players have eight pieces each, called "Kibs." In the first phase, they take turns placing pieces on a five by seven board (with the center node missing), trying to form a "KIBIK" (four pieces in a row). A KIBIK allows a player to remove an opponent's piece. After all pieces are placed, the second phase begins where players are allowed to slide pieces and make more KIBIKs. When a player is reduced to four pieces a jumping move is allowed. The player to first remove five of the opponent's pieces wins.

name: Colossus!
description:
Colossus! is a free boardgame pitting giant monsters fighting each other on the tabletop. The game is presented as a generic ruleset, all players need is available using components they can build themselves or from other games and toys - most players won't need to buy anything they don’t own already.

The game lets players build giant monsters, called colossi, using three types of Power Cards: Abilities, Attacks and Specials. Abilities represent the inherent skills and characteristics of the colossus. Specials are the unexpected and unique moves which colossi can perform in battle. Attacks and Attack modifiers represent any weapons and ways of fighting that the colossus might have including claws, teeth, horns, laser beams, rockets, atomic breath, a sharp beak, fireballs, etc.

The game is played on a 1/600 tabletop with no hexes or squares. There are 6 types of terrain: cities, hazardous, wet, high, tricky or industrial parks. Given the huge size of the colossi, these are little more than nuisances to their inexorable advance.

The game is played in turns broken in 8 phases: Air Strike Planning (determine where they land - random), Orders (draw Orders Cards and assign them to colossi under your command), Movement (move colossi based on Order Card), Ranged Attack (use Ranged Attacks if any), Close Attack (use Close Attacks if any), Tinies (move the human defenders towards closes colossus and attack it), Air Strike Attack (roll for damage on colossi under air strike coordinates), End (remove markers, check if somebody won, etc). The game ends when a side's colossi have all been knocked out or when a scenario's victory conditions are met (the rules come with 6 scenarios)

Colossus! comes with its own setting called The Zillium Wars which is featured in little snippets across the rules. This story-world has been deliberately left vague and open to the player’s imagination. A range of possible colossi are suggested as starting points, but players are free to come up with their own concepts and model them using the cards available... or even invent their own cards! Hopefully there will be enough active players out there feeding back on the rules and how they use them so I can keep improving and expanding Colossus!
mechanics: Action Queue, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Spiral Game
description:
Players fill the snail board with the wooden rings. On a player's turn, the player quickly checks all the rings on the board to see if the colour underneath the ring is the same as the ring's colour. If this is the case, the player picks those rings up. Before the next player's turn, the rings are pushed together and new rings refilled from the cloth bag. At the end of the game, the player with the most rings wins.

Components: colourful snail board, 60 wooden rings in 4 colours, cloth bag, rules.

name: Hatfield vs McCoy
description:
Hatfield vs. McCoy is a turn based card game of hillbilly combat and strategy. Each family deck contains character cards for that family. Players will use family cards in combination with action cards against other player’s families.

The fate of your family is determined by the defense of your farm while doing all that you can to eliminate any family that opposes you.

A standard game has 148 cards divided into three decks. Two deck's of 20 family cards, and one shared deck of action cards. Each player will also have 20 farm tokens.

Each player will start with three family members in play and three action cards in their hand. Each round players will equip their family members, then declare if they are going to fight or call for back up and bring more family in play.

If one or both players declare that they want to fight, they will send family members to fight.

During the fight action cards, equipment cards and traits on the family members will be added. The family with the highest number will win. The family with the lower number, loses all family members and equipment in the fight. Any excess damage (the difference between the two team totals) will be taken out of the farm tokens of the losing family.

The family that runs out of family members or tokens loses, and the other family wins the game.

name: Trading Paint
description: Trading Paint is an easy game with a good mix of luck and simple strategy. It’s a press-your-luck type of race game where the bigger chance you take, the farther you can move on your turn but also the larger chance of losing your turn altogether.

name: Creature Quest
description:
Creature Quest is a storytelling game in which you're given a random Creature, super Power, Weakness, Personality, and Quest to complete. Explain how your horrible creature would solve the given problem-- but watch out! The other players are just waiting to instill some divine intervention into your story to screw you up.

Your goal is to overcome new narrative obstacles to generate a cohesive story in which your creature completes its given chore. The other players determine how successful your story is in presenting a consistent and well-crafted tale through "Approval" cards. The player whose story receives the most Approval wins!
categories: Card Game, Humor, Party Game, Print & Play

name: Stellar Dawn
description:
The Galactic Empire has fallen, and now many races are looking to seize power.

The game board displays multiple sectors of space, each containing spaces for cards represnting planets, space-stations, etc that you can influence to gain resources/abilities. Using those resources to increase your influence in other sectors to expand your empire and earn final victory.

Each of the 12 rounds consists of the following phases:
1. Players choose 1 of the 7 action cards secretly, and pass the remaining cards clockwise until all players have chosen. These cards determine the player order for the round, and income.
2. In player order, players pay to place their influence cube on a planet/system card and take any immediate rewards.
3. Players earn resources for each cube on a planet/system that has an ongoing effect.
4. Each player that controls a sector (most cubes) gains that sector's bonus (VP or resources)

Once all planet/system cards are full, or at the end of the 12th round, the game ends and the player with the most VP wins!

name: Umspannwerk Werkstattheft
description:
5 additional cards for Umspannwerk base game.

Players must stretch the rubber band on the 3 x 3 little poles with as few move as possible so that the final result fits with the band´s position on his card.
The player using least moves to reach the positions on his/her cards is the winner.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game

name: Ich schenke dir ....!
description:
There are 27 cards and three 3x3 boards with pictures.

Player try to describe the item from the card and other must guess what it is. They may observe the boards. First player with the correct answer get the card as a point.

Player with the most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

name: Remagon
description: The playing board consists of 96 hexagonal spaces. There are 48 spaces in a central diamond pattern, and four groups of 12 "home" spaces attached to the edge of the diamond area. Each player starts with 12 pawns. A certain number are exchanged with opponents, depending on the number of players. There is a placement phase where all pawns are placed. Players place pawns to make it difficult for their opponents to get their pawns home. Players move their pawns; the first to get them all in the appropriate home space wins. Movement types allowed include trading places, jumping, or sliding. A pawn may be stranded if it has no neighbors.

name: Galt Anymals
description: Draw from a pile of animals parts printed on square 2"x2" cardboard tiles as you try to complete "correct" animal forms. Points are scored both for completed animals and for animals that are built "correctly." Player with the highest score wins.

name: Book Bug Game
description:
An instructional game, designed to increase familiarity with books and interest in reading them. Intended for teachers and librarians.

Players take turns drawing Question cards, which have trivia questions based on children's literature. Depending on their answer, they may advance or retreat on a track, and may draw another card. If questions and answers are not read aloud, the player retreats one space. The first player to reach the 'finish' space wins.

The cards are of several types, some which send the player back spaces, some which send the player forward, and some with open-ended questions intended to inspire further interest in reading.

The named 'special' spaces on the board do not appear to have any game effect, but the characters depicted are given write-ups, as are the Book Bugs themselves, in the 'activity pamphlet'.

name: Sherlock's Safety First Game
description:
Designed to teach youngsters about various hazards and safe behavior.

Players draw cards listing safety tips and dangerous acts, which cause players to advance for safety, retreat for carelessness. Spaces on the board allow an extra draw or lost turn, may allow shortcuts or cause backtracking.

Recommended for players aged 3-8 - but I think the pawns may be a choking hazard for players under 5!

name: The Salmon Game
description:
The Salmon Game recreates the life-cycle of the Pacific salmon, including migration, survival, and spawning. The salmon must successfully negotiate rivers, lakes, and oceans, while avoiding such hazards as disease, dams, fishermen, pollution, predators, etc. Ultimately, they must spawn as many salmon as they can in order to increase their chances of winning the game.

Each player is given a "fish block" (which represents their salmon) and a set of chips (which represent their roe and, therefore, potential offspring). The game-play is quite simple, as players use their "fish block" to follow a path of spaces (similar to the Game of Life), and they use a die to determine how far they move in a given turn. Once the spawning grounds have been reached, further die rolls are used to determine how many fish are born.

The winner is the player with the most fish left when all players have reached the finish square.

name: Fair Play: Spelet som ger kunskap om rättvis handel
description: Fair Play is themed around the relationship between rich and poor countries. Each player has a role: producer, importer, shopkeepers or consumer. In the game there are seven countries in every continent there players can invest. When a player lands on a square with a question mark, the player must answer a question from a questionnaire booklet, in areas such as social studies, geography and history. The winner is the one getting most points at the end of the game.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Nominoes & Trickets
description:
Nominoes & Trickets is a tile-based game that shares some similarities with Tri-Ominos and Trimino. Its red plastic tiles (56 in the 1960s edition, 36 in the 1980s edition) are triangles with zero to five white dots along each side (not in the tile’s corners).

In the game’s main variant, "Nominoes", players draw tiles to decide who places the opening tile, then take turns attempting to place a tile (from their hand of 9) in a way that that will add up the dots from the tiles’ open ends into a multiple of 5. (The open ends are pieces to which two sides remain unmatched to other pieces.) This total is added to the player’s score. There is a bonus for placing a tile in such a way to close a loop of tiles, as there is for blocking an opponent from play. The first player to reach 500 points wins.

There is also a second variant of the rules called "Trickets". It is similar to the card game Bridge.

name: Enclose5
description:
Abstract game for 2 players; can be played on plain grid paper, each player using a pen of different color.
Rules:
1. each player alternately place a mark of his color inside an empty cell of the grid.
2. if player completes a closed polygonal with his marks, all the internal cells (empty or marked) take that color. A player can enlarge one of his existing polygonals by adding new marks.
(a closed polygonal is any closed path connecting marks of the same color, each adjacent horizontally, vertically or diagonally to next one)
3. the cells, once colored, are blocked. They cannot change their color even when they are enclosed in a new polygonal of the opposite color and do not take part to any alignment of marks
4.If a player makes a winning alignment of 5 or more marks (horizontally, vertically or diagonally), he gains additional moves: 1 for an alignment of 5, 2 for an alignment of 6, and so on (for n signs, n-4 moves, with n≥5). Additional moves must be played in the same turn of play but cannot be used to increase in lenght a winning alignment built in the same turn;
if an additional move makes a different winning alignment, the gained moves add up.
5. if a move closes a polygonal, the coloring of its internal cells is mandatory and has the priority over marks alignments.
Goal of the game:
to color an arranged number of cells, by default 20. Players can choose a different number at the beginning of the match.

name: Electronimoes
description:
Object of the game Electronimoes: Collect the most points while connecting the atom cards into molecular creations in the center of the table. The cards fit together a bit like dominoes. They are inspired by atoms and how many bonds each atom can make by sharing electrons with other atoms - thus the name.

Shuffle the cards and deal out 7 cards to each player. Place remaining cards in the center of the table and place the top card face up on the table. There are three kinds of cards; regular atom cards can make single, double, or triple bonds to other atom cards, for which you get single, double or triple points; noble gas cards do not bond to any cards; ion cards only fit with one other card. First player looks at the card on the table and at the cards in their hand.

If their is an oxygen card that can make two single bonds on the table, for example, first player needs to have a card in their hand that can also make a single bond. This is easy to see by the design of the cards. If the quality of the lines fit together, you have a bond. An oxygen is worth 8 points. If you bond a hydrogen to it, worth 1 point, you would get a total of 8 points for this move. If this player does not have any single bonding cards, they could also play a noble gas, if they have one. Neon, for example, would be worth ten points. They would then put this noble gas card in their winnings stack. They could also play an ion card. Sodium, for example, would be worth 11 points, but it would stay on the table. If NONE of these options is available, they must draw from the deck until they get a card that matches the one up on the table.

If a player is the last one to place an atom card onto the growing molecule in the middle of the table, meaning their are no more empty slots to bond any cards to, they not only get their points, but they get to keep all the cards in this molecule. They stack up the cards and put it in their winnings pile, along with noble gasses or ion cards won. In order to win the ion cards, a player must have the other half of the arrow pictured on the ion card. They get the points for both cards, and then put them in their stack. When one player has run out of cards, players add up the points they earned, plus ONE point for each card in their winnings stack. They then subtract any points left in their hand. If desired, play up to 200 points, or end the game after all players have had a chance to go first.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Educational, Math

name: Rock Bottom
description:
Rock Bottom is game geared towards adult players who try to eliminate the other players by making them hit rock bottom. This is accomplished by playing cards on either the other player or yourself to either give or take assets. The objective is to make all other players lose all their money, their spouse,their children, their job and their home.

Rock Bottom features cards that fit players with a somewhat twisted sense of humor, as the cards that are played inspire trash talking the friends that you are playing with. Simple rules keep the game moving fast, and the laughs always following.

name: Sternrupfen
description:
Children's memory game. Each child gets a dodecagon (12 sided shape) in their chosen colour. The 60 pieces represent rays that will emanate from the dodecagon.

Shuffle the pieces and spread them out. Now the players select a piece in their turn and if it is their colour, they may add it to one of the sides of their dodecagon. The first to finish their star with 12 correct rays, wins.

name: Three Dice Brick
description:
Three Dice Brick is a very addictive high scoring dice game in which one or more players roll for points. The player with the highest score of 3,000+ points in the final round of play wins the game. Once a player has achieved a winning point total of 3,000+ points each other player has one last turn to score enough points to surpass that high-score. Otherwise, any roll of the dice which results in a Sudden Death scoring combination is an automatic loss unless the other player throws a Single 1 scoring combination to reset the game. Three Dice Brick is played similarly to Six Dice Farkle, Cee-Lo and Cosmic Wimpout with a few variations. It comes with custom designed three translucent glow-n-the dark dice in a small clear plastic bag, score sheet and comprehensive instruction manual.

Gambling Style:

As a gambling game Three Dice Brick can arouse a great deal of excitement if played for a small stake. Each one of the players must contribute a similar fee to the pot. The one who finishes first wins the pot. There is no second place money and/or prizes! For those interested in the bar/club version of Three Dice Brick™ it’s often played to determine a loser who must buy drinks for the other player(s), e.t.c.

Tournament Style:

Three Dice Brick™ tournaments can be held at house parties, local taverns, high school/college campuses, churches, clubs/bars, recreational facilities, civic centers, social networking sites, e.t.c. for whatever prize award individual Three Dice Brick™ clubs deem appropriate and winners can be awarded championship status or titles (i.e. Three Dice Brick King, Brick Master, Three Dice Brick Champion, e.t.c.). Three Dice Brick tournaments can be played by having players compete at several tables- with the winners at each table advancing to a final table for a Three Dice Brick head-to-head championship. The tournament feature of Three Dice Brick is especially entertaining for evening events at night since the dice are glow-n-the dark it makes for fun and competitive tournament play!
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Set Collection

name: The College Boat Race
description:
"College Boat Race" shows the sport of rowing. The actual board is fixed to the inside box bottom. The walls of the box bottom are made of wood, covered with decorative paper. Components: four wooden "men" playing pieces and a cardboard spinner with a metal arrow. Game board shows a u-shaped track around an island with a boat house at the shore and a house on a hill, track surrounded by many types of boats and an island in the upper right corner;directions printed on the underside of the box cover.
Players spin a spinner and go around the track. You must finish the game by exact count in order to win.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Number Jungle
description: Number Jungle is an educational board game which increases the players' knowledge of math. The object of the game is for players to race around the board while encountering math problems along the way. Two to six players can play the game. The player to finish first is the winner but other players can continue until they finish.

name: Banzai Zeppelin!
description:
Objective: Be the fastest on a circumnavigation of the world
- moving by turns -
simple 'Roll & Move' game with following mdifications:
1 ending on a space with flags add or subtract additional spaces
2 you have to reach stopovers within a diven time (days); if you don't achieve it you're out
3 the earlier you reach a stopover the more you achieve bonus cards (waiting for the other players)
4 game ends at Friedrichshafen after all players arrived; player with most bonus cards wins

remarks:
published probably 1930
categories: Aviation / Flight, Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Racing, Travel

name: Der blinde Passagier im Zeppelin
description:
Objective: be the first getting all of the meeples in your home base on board of the Zeppelin
- acting by turns -
each player starts with 6 meeples, placed on her/his home base;
roll the die: if it shows a 1 - 5, place one of your meeples onto the correspondent waiting position; with a '6' it ends up with a safe seat in the cabin. Turn ends after a '6' or if all waiting positions are occupied; if not - it's up to the active player to roll the die again.But if a waiting position is occupied you must take that meeple and put it into your home base.
remarks:
published ~1920/30s
due to the fact that these kind of games were played for money players must 'bought into'; before the game started they had to draw a chip - top was neutral, reverse was yellow or (in one case) black. The lucky one (socalled fare dodger) got her/his stake back at the end of the game - no matter what position.

name: GODS: Intervention
description:
GODS: Intervention is a fast strategic tile placement game set in the early years of human civilization. Players represent gods that influence the civilizations by granting them skills they may use to develop.

GODS does not use any board. It is played directly on any table. In each players turn they choose to pick and place one of the five different tiles available; a temple or one of the skills; Architecture, Conflict, Culture or Trade. Temples represent a headquarter for your devotees and may be placed anywhere on the table except in a civilization you already have a temple or next to another temple. Skills must be placed adjacent and orthogonal to another tile.

Placing a skill activates the surrounding and adjacent tiles. Choose between using their effects or to collect points.

Each game uses a set amount of each tile and as soon as one of the different tiles are run out the game ends. At that time the player with most points of the skill they have least of wins.

GODS is a brain burner. Players needs to be strategic while it is extremely difficult to predict the other players moves. A conflict may arise to destroy en entire civilization or through trade a civilization may loose much of its competence.

name: Im weissen Rössl
description:
Objective: be the first to reach your home base with all (4) meeples
- moving by turns -
'Eile mit Weile/Pachisi' variant with following modifications
1 the number stepping out of the base and another die roll is the "1".
If you don't use the "1" to step out, ist counts double and you may roll again.
2 you can't be thrown out if your meeple rests on a 'bank'
3 you block all others if there a two meeples (same color) on the same space

The game was published about 1932.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Race, Roll / Spin and Move, Static Capture, Track Movement

name: Game of Black Cat
description:
From McLoughlin & Sons 1885

"Game of Black Cat" card game with 53 playing cards, two counters and an instruction booklet in a paper covered cardboard box; playing cards have printed images of cat parts such as whiskers, hind paws, eyes etc. on one side; box cover lithographed with the image of a black cat's head;

name: Domain: Lords of Ether
description:
Domain is a tabletop card game for 2-4 players, or up to 8 players during team play matches. It focuses on a world building element, where all players contribute to an ever expanding playing field. Roads connect to Soul Wells, which are used to score the game and provide the magical energy players use to summon monsters or cast hexes. Players move along the system of rolls with a dice roll. Roads may also have other effects, such as reducing movement over harsh terrain, or increasing a player's draw.

Summoned Monster cards may be stationed in a controlled Soul Well to guard them against other players, or left in a player's hand, so that they may attempt to conquer other players' Soul Wells. So there is a strong balance between defending your territory, while having enough strength to expand into enemy territory as well. Hexes are used to manipulate the playing field, support combat or increase draw capacity.
When combat does occur, it has been designed to be accessible and casual, in which battles may be resolved quickly and easily without complex counting or score keeping mechanisms. This keeps the focus of the game on strategic use of the world and unique card abilities to play to a Soul Well's power.

By matching Soul Well or monster Domains with your Lord's (player token piece), a player can boost the power of his creatures, and make his territory more difficult to conquer, or activate specific Domain abilities for his monsters.

An average game takes 30 minutes to an hour for 2 people and 1 hour to 3 for 4 players. It all depends on how players shape their gaming world :)
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Hand Management, Memory, Roll / Spin and Move, Tile Placement

name: Pet Frenzied
description:
Pet Frenzied is played with thirteen pet cards and thirteen matching house cards.

Before the game starts, the pet cards are hidden (facedown) in the play area. Each player that receives a house card and goes in search of the matching pet. When they find it, they take a new house card and go in search of the next pet. This continues until all pets have been found. Whomever has found the most pets at the end of the game wins.

name: Magic Miles
description: Game about travel with Auto, Train or Bus. Each player tries to find, while en route, the objects named on the cards he has drawn. Player scoring the most points after all the cards are exhausted is the winner.

name: Cross Country Marathon
description:
The object of the game to see which of the players is first to cover the course from New York to Los Angeles, stopping in each of the cities en route.
The players spin the dial and move their runners as many spaces as is indicated.
The first player to move his runner into Los Angeles wins the race.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: War of Nations
description:
Each player places one counter, representing army, on each of his five starting places. Players moves they armies as the dial indicated.
The player wins when he has captured all the opposing armies.

name: Cluster Luck
description: This is a press your luck game playable on a Byzantine Chessboard. In the game, players try to cluster their pieces into groups to score more points (players score bonus points for their largest group). players roll two dice and move around a lane, leaving a piece behind. If they land on a space they landed on prior, they end up losing all points in the round. Bonus points are awarded for forming larger groups. Players have to decide when to quit, as is typical of a press your luck game, and failure to do so and landing on a space occupied prior results in no points earned for the round. Players have to decide when to either quit or push forward.

name: Omada
description:
This is the game Groups adapted to a Byzantine Chessboard, with 8 pieces aside, instead of 6, as seen in Groups. In this game players attempt to get their pieces on the board connected into a single group of orthogonally (vertically and/or horizontally) connected pieces, after being connected diagonally only. Pieces start out adjacent to one another, and a player's pieces are all connected diagonally at the start of the game.

In the game, pieces move orthgonally, and stop on an empty space, with players alternating moves one piece at a time until one player wins.

Omada is Greek for the word "group".

name: Circle Link
description:
This is a connection game playable on a Byzantine Chessboard. In the game, players try to be the first to connect the inner part of the board to the outer part of the board, by either placing pieces from their reserve off the board, onto an empty space, or by sliding from inside or outside. Players start with 16 pieces off the board, which can end up being recycled and relocated.

A win in the game consists of a player being able to trace a path of spaces occupied with their own pieces vertically or horizontally (not diagonally), linking the inner and outer circle of the board.

name: Lane Checkers
description:
This game is a game in the Checkers family, playable on a Byzantine Chessboard. In the game players will advance checkers that stay in a lane when moving, and may end up switching lanes when performing a jump capture. A piece may also switch lanes if it promotes to a King piece.

On a Byzantine chess board, it has 4 rows and 16 columns. Pieces stay in the row they are in during place, and only switch rows when jumping. In the game there are 4 pieces per row per player, and players have a total of 24 pieces a side.

name: Lane Backgammon
description:
This is a game in the Backgammon family, playable on a Byzantine Chessboard. The game is similar to regular backgammon, except pieces start out in home area, and are divided up into a number of lanes, rather than all fitting into one lane, as is seen in regular Backgammon.

Player attempt to get all their pieces go around the board and have them land on enemy home spaces to bear off. Players may only do this if they have all their home spaces empty. When hit, pieces go back to their home spaces, rather than off the board on a bar. Players start with 4 pieces per lane (row), and have a total of 16 pieces to start per side.

name: Doom Dome
description:
This is a roll and move game (also playable without the use of dice) on a Byzantine Chessboard. Object of the game is to be the last remaining player. In the game players will in the regular game, move as far as a single six sided die the roll tells them to, trying to avoid barriers put up in the game by players as they move. In the game, as players get eliminated, they end up removing barriers the drop as the move. The game feels a bit light a light cycle race.

Object of the game is to be the last remaining player.

In the diceless variant, player's movement is governed by what other pieces are on the board.

name: Sectorian
description: This is an abstract strategy game playable on a Byzantine Chessboard. In the game, players move their Sectorian spaceships along the intersections of the board, capturing spaces on the board, in order to be able to produce more spaceships. Object of the game is to be the first player to get 8 of their spaceships on the board.

name: ViciGo
description:
ViciGo is a 2 player abstract strategy game playable on a Byzantine chess board.

In the game, players will move their pieces on the board, to either perform a custodial (bookend) capture to remove enemy pieces, or to perform a "bloom" pattern around one of their own pieces, in order to capture spaces on the board.

First player to get a set number of their pieces on the board wins.

name: Arachnid Trap War
description:
This is a 2 player abstract strategy game, playable on a Byzantine Chessboard. In the game, players will move their pieces and try to capture enemy pieces by bookending enemy pieces between their own pieces, so the enemy pieces get frozen so they can't move. A player will then end up moving one unfrozen pieces that is freezing an enemy piece and occupying a space to capture it. A player is also able to leave a piece behind, if the player doesn't move one of their pieces next to an enemy piece (or have that piece moving perform a capture).

The game includes 3 play levels, the first one without a King/Queen/Royal piece, and then a second which adds one Royal piece, and a third variant which has the player have two Royal pieces. Each level of play adds addition win conditions.

The trap and delayed capture are reused from the likes of King's Cross and Linebreakers.

name: Sow and Erode
description:
Board;
The board is four concentric circle with 16 space each (aka a Byzantine Chessboard).

Setup:
The 32 Black and 32 white pieces are alternated like a circular checkerboard.

Rules:
This game is a two player abstract strategy game in the Mancala family. As players sow their pieces, the board position "erodes" and leaves the players fewer and fewer options, and more and more spaces to sow pieces into to be removed from the board.

Object of the game is for a player to capture more of their opponent's pieces than their opponent captured of theirs.

name: Stimmt doch gar nicht!
description:
Educational game where children must carefully listen to the story and find the mistakes in that story grabbing the items or cards from the table. There are 26 items and 26 cards in this game what may included on the stories.

Player who has the most cards/items at the end of the game is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Real-time
publishers: Der Kleine Verlag, Erhard Friedrich Verlag

name: Reise um die Welt
description:
Objective: be the first turning back to Europe (40)
- moving by turns -
simple 'Roll & Move' game; ending on a red marked space follow instructions glued into lid;
remarks:
should have been published ~1920's

name: Die Reise nach der Sonne
description:
Objective: be the first reaching the top (sun)
- moving by turns -
each player rolls two colored dice choosing one of the shown colors to move along. Throwing the same colors player may choose this color or roll again.
remarks:
due to design game should have been produced during 1950's or earlier.

name: Wir jagen mit der Kamera
description:
Objective: gain as many winning points as possible taking photographs from wild animals.
- moving by turns -
simple 'Roll & Move' game; ending on a 'pictured' space you may collect appropiate card be the first one, otherwise collect winning points only. Some spaces send you back or forwards...
remarks:
game - as usual for GDR products - praises socialist countries..
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Hydra
description:
Hydra is a game for two players to test their mental ability and logical thinking against each other. With a look and feel of game that could have been played by men of the Norse whilst they drank and feasted in their Mead halls or even taken on the raiding trips and played at sea. Hydra is a completely new game of intelligence and cunning, you must create an unbroken line of tiles from one side of the board to the other whilst stopping your opponent from doing the same. The first person to do so wins the game.

A unique feature of Hydra is that it is played East to West and North to South or it could be West to East and South to North. The game gets its name from the style of play of creating lines that get broken like they have been cut and then you must start a new one, just like when Hercules cut off one head of the Hydra another new one or two grow back. The game mechanics are very simple with only three different types of tiles and a single hand count of rules to beat your opponent.

Game play can take just a couple of minutes when you first learn to play, up to tens of minutes or more as you and your opponents learn the subtle flow of cunning tactics that are wrapped in Hydra.

name: Imperio
description:
The game combined the "capture the leader" and geometric movement aspects of games like Chess, Xiangqi or Shogi with custodial capture such as is found in games like Petteia or Hnefatafl. Because capture then involves a combination of two pieces, control of the board is consciously distinguished from simply the ability to move to any given space. Hence, it resembles Chess up to a point but players have to think about relative positioning of their own pieces in combination and of the opponent's pieces to see what areas of the board they control.

Imperio is the Latin word which refers to having complete control over someone, to the power of life and death in principle. This game is about control of the board, which entails the power of life and death (so to speak) over the opponent's pieces. One has to think differently from most games average people today would know to achieve that type of control effectively.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Point to Point Movement

name: Meltdown: Save the Polar Bears Before the Ice Melts
description:
The first board game that melts

GEOlino, the German science magazine for children, wanted its young readers to experience the effects of global warming. Not with dry-as-dust theory, but in a completely child-oriented way. That's why we've developed MELTDOWN - the first board game that melts.

The aim of the game is to take a polar bear family from the permanent ice floes to safety on the mainland. It's a race against time, as the way leads across real, slowly melting ice floes, which children can make themselves with the accompanying mould, a bit of water and a freezer compartment. The chunks of ice are arranged on a blue polar sea sponge to form a small Arctic. The sponge is used as the game board and absorbs the melted ice at the same time. Now you can start saving polar bears.

MELTDOWN makes children experience the effects of global warming in a playful way. Without any wagging finger - just one hand to roll the dice.

name: Kindness Kingdom
description:
Proudly made in the USA, the board game is ideal for 2 to 4 players. Not only do children develop social and emotional skills but thoughtfulness toward others. Once a winner is determined, players are requested to cheer on the remaining players until all youngsters reach the finish line, arriving at Queen Grace's marvelous tea party. Subtle illustrations such as a princess seated in a wheelchair reinforce empathy, a much-needed skill for kids to combat teasing or worse, bullying.

Be the first to collect all 8-neighborhood charms, the key to the Golden Gate of the Golden Rule and enter the royal tea party. As players make their way around the Kingdom, watch out for the 4 Slippery Slopes of Bad Manners and the 4 Faux Pas Spaces. Rainbow Baguettes and baby Daisy Fairy spaces help little princesses with shortcuts into the Golden Gate of the Golden Rule. Naturally, with the best of good manners, remaining players are to be cheered on as they make their way to the tea party. To keep the game fresh play after play, there are a whopping 368 question cards.

Beyond the board game, parents can keep up with their niceties by visiting Queen Grace on her Facebook Page, also called "Kindness Kingdom" where she imparts pearls of wisdom.

name: Filly Witchy: Hexentanz in Zimsala
description:
A Filly Witchy themed roll-and-move game in which players try to reach the center of the board first in order to win the "magical flight into the center of glittering magic".

Game play
The board shows 6 concentric circles. With the exception of the innermost circle, all the circles are divided into several spaces. Some spaces have a diamond symbol with a number printed on them.
Each player gets a Filly figure as their player token and puts it on one of the start spaces on the outermost circle. Players taken turns rolling the six-sided die and move their token accordingly in the direction shown by an arrow (players don't have to use the full pips, i. e. when they roll a 5 they may move 1-5 spaces). If a player lands on a space marked with a diamond, he/she may move one circle closer to the center if their next roll is equal or higher than the number in the diamond. If a player ends his/her turn on a space occupied by another player's token, he/she may put that token on a space of their choice one circle further away from the center.

The game ends when a player token reaches the center of the board. This player wins the game.

name: Zirkus Zotty
description:
A circus-themed roll-and-move game with a memory element.

Goal
Be the first to reach the finish space.

Setup
The board shows a racing course consisting of coloured spaces, each showing one of 10 different symbols. 10 chips show the same symbols on one side. The chips are randomly distributed in the middle of the board, face down. Each player gets a pawn, which they place at the start space.

Game play
Players take turns rolling the colour die. The active player moves his/her pawn to the next space of that colour. Then he/she has to turn over one of the chips. If it shows the same symbol as the space this player's pawn is currently on, they get to stay. If it is a different symbol, they have to move back to the space with that symbol.
The first player to reach the finish space wins the game.

name: Zotty: ABC Bingo
description:
A bingo game that practices recognizing letters.

Each player has a tableau of picture tiles. Players take turns spinning the spinner, which shows all the letters of the alphabet. All players try to find a picture depicting something that starts with that letter in their tableau. If they find a matching one, they turn it over to the other side (which shows the letter instead of the picture).

The first player to have turned over a horizontal, vertical or diagonal row of tiles wins the game.

name: Zotty: Gute Nacht
description:
A children's game about matching shapes.

Each player gets a number of picture cards. Players take turns rolling the colour die and move the Zotty pawn to a space of their choice in that colour. If the player has the card that matches the shadow image on that space, they get to place their card on the shadow space. If the player doesn't have the matching card, nothing happens.

The first player to get rid of all their cards wins the game.

name: Zotty: Rate Zoo
description:
An animal-themed guessing game for children.

Players take turns drawing a face-down animal card from a stack. Only one player gets to see which animal it is. All the other players take turns asking a yes/no question, trying to find out what animal it is. If a player thinks he/she knows what animal it is, they name it on their turn. If it is correct, they win the card. After each question, the Zotty pawn is moved one space. If Zotty reaches the end of the track (= after twelve questions) before the animal has been guessed, nobody wins the card.

The game ends after a number of rounds (to be agreed upon by the players at the start of the game) has been played. The player with the most cards wins the game.

name: Stuka das packende Kampffliegerspiel
description:
Objective:
be the first reaching space '88';
- moving by turns -
'Roll & Move' game, very similar to Chutes and Ladders
differences: above space 70 players may choose using one die instead of two.

remarks:
should had been published late 1930's/early 40's
categories: Aviation / Flight, Children's Game, Dice, Racing, World War II

name: Xalvage
description: Xalvage is a sci-fi trading, exploration, and combat boardgame. Players select a starship and move it along spaces on the board, collecting Discovery tokens and revealing encounters with other ships or special events. Ships can be friendly and traded with, like science crews or other merchants, or hostile like aliens and pirates. Events can be things like losing a turn from a faulty hyperdrive or discovering a new element. Players get rewarded (or lose) salvage from these encounters. Salvage can be used to buy upgrades to their ship, increasing firepower, shields, maneuverability, and so on. Combat is played out with rolling different dice. Xalvage points are won at the end of each fully explored sector, and are counted by adding up Discovery tokens. At the end of the game, whoever has collected the most Xalvage points wins.
categories: Adventure, Card Game, Dice, Science Fiction, Space Exploration
mechanics: Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Point to Point Movement

name: Throne Maker
description:
Throne Maker is an express style dice game inspired by Kingdom Builder in which players take it in turns over a series of rounds to roll, match and arrange dice in order to score. The player with the highest score at the end of the final round wins the game.

Each round the criteria for scoring changes as the Throne Makers with influence are randomly rolled. Special ability tokens and the opportunity to influence the next player's score all feature in game play.

This game was created as an entry in the 2013 PnP Express/In-a-tin competition and therefore the initial version is designed to be as compact and portable as possible.

name: The Mad Sad Glad Game
description: Each player is dealt five white Feelings Cards. The Judge (non-active player) draws a pink Situation Card and reads it. Players who have a Feeling card that matches how they would feel shout out the name of the feeling and lay the card down on the matching area on the board. The Judge adjudicates who was first and whether the feeling was a good match. Once a single card is accepted (players may argue the correctness of their card with the Judge), the Judge passes the Situation cards to the next player to the left, who becomes the new Judge, and play resumes. First player to get rid of all their Feelings cards is the winner.

name: Chain Links
description:
This is a light weight card game for up to six players, ages 5 and up. The goal is to keep the chain of links (cards) going. The deck is made of a count up/count down card, four different colored links numbering 1-12 in each color, and flip cards. The first person to play all their cards wins the game.

There are five short rules for the game.
1) Never play a card that has the same color as the top card in the chain.
2) If Count Up is facing up, the value of your card must be higher than the top card of the chain, unless you play a Flip card. Likewise, if Count Down is facing up, the value of your card must be smaller than the top card of the chain, unless you play a Flip.
3) The three ways to flip the Count Down / Count Up card is to play a 1, play a 12, or play a flip. If you play a 1 this flips the Count Down card to Count Up. Play a 12 and the Count Up card to Count Down. If you play a Flip, the Count Up / Count Down card to the opposite side.
4) When a Flip is played, the color of the Flip is what is used for Rule #1, and the value of the card under the Flip is the value you use for Rule #2 depending on what side the Count Up / Count Down is face up.
5) If you can not play a card, draw one from the draw pile. If you can play the card drawn, do so, if not play passes to the next person. If there are no more cards to draw from shuffle all but the last two cards of the chain up and make them the draw deck.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Number, Print & Play

name: The Penguins of Madagascar: Go Time
description:
A fast-paced game of recognition and reaction. Players are dealt cards showing the Penguins and their friends in various poses.

As each scene card is turned over, players race to be the first to identify characters or items in the scene that match one of their cards. The first player to have matched and discarded all their cards wins the game.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Parli-Cards
description:
Parli-cards is a curious blend of trivia and traditional card games. Included are two decks that feature portraits of the current (for 2011) Senate, two decks of easy and hard trivia questions, four bags of different color bingo chips and a hardback gameboard depicting the United States with the electoral votes marked on each state.

Several games are outlined that parallel rummy, war and poker (but are called POTUS, Filibuster and Veto). Can also be played as a straight trivia game. The games incorporate the senators in play too. For instance, the poker variant holds a full house with senators from the same state in higher rank than a full house that does not.

Apparently there is also a version that features all the presidents and vice presidents with appropriate trivia questions.

name: Murder in the Puszta
description:
Situated on the edge of the Puszta National Park and about a mile from the nearest village, the Riders Inn is the perfect spot for tourists to experience traditional Hungarian customs and culture. But suddenly a dead body is found...

This is a murder mystery party game for 8 players. Everyone acts out the part of a suspect in a murder case. Over the course of a dinner, players cross-examine each other.
This murder mystery game differs from the usual boxed versions in one respect – the players won't get a character booklet at the beginning of the party which would gradually reveal new information. Instead they are given advance character information to read through before the party. "Murder in the Puszta" is based on real life insomuch as everybody already knows at the beginning of the evening everything they did and saw before. Even so, there is no need to learn anything by heart since during the game players can always look up details.

name: Buffalo Bill
description:
In this game from 1898, players are trying to accumulate 10 buffalo in order to win using a spin-and-move mechanic.

A players turn consists of using the spinner, moving the indicated number of spaces, then completing any actions their space requires.

The spaces are either blank (nothing happens), a buffalo head (the player receives one point), "Captured by Indians" (the player loses a turn), and various spaces moving the player back.

If a player makes it around the board back to "Camp", they start again and go around the board.

The first player to accumulate 10 points and make it back to Camp wins the game.

name: Crossing the Ocean
description:
In this game, players are trying to accumulate $100,000 or more in cargo from foreign ports.

Players place their game piece on a starting port on the West side of the game board. Players then spin the "compass" to see which direction they are able to move that turn. Once determined, they can move any number of spaces in that direction (at least one). Players cannot move onto spaces occupied by other players or that depict land or other ships.

When a player lands on a port, they receive the indicated value of cargo. Values range from $25,000 to $75,000. A player cannot get cargo from the same spot twice, so a player must visit a minimum of two ports to win.

As soon as a player's cargo totals $100,000 or more, they win the game.

name: Black Rain
description:
Black Rain is a cooperative adventure game themed around tragical figures, who tries to escape their Destiny or to fullfill it. The players choose from 12 Characters and lead them through the streets of the Dark City. With each location they reach, new events unfold, which alterate their destinys and unlock skills and knowledge about the backgroundstory of the Dark City. The more the players explore their Destinies, collecting Destiny-Markers and unlock Events, the harder their struggles become.

Each player taking a Character Card, with some Traits and a Portrait, additionally taking 2 more treat Cards, to have variations. Than he choose his Destiny Cards, a Katharsis Card and a Hybris Card, which define his aims in Play and which Destiny Tokens he has to collect.
After the players collect their Destiny-Markers acording to their hidden Cards, they activate their Destiny Cards, which contains a final Event. The more Events they unlock, the more Cards will be in their Hand, combining Deckdrafting rules with Co-Op-Gameplay.
Booth destinies can be fullfilled or broken, with strong effects on the character. There will be a Board/Citymap ala Arkham Horror, with events taking place on different locations by eventcards. This Cards can contain challenges or encounters, causing the player to throw a dice and try to use skills of their characters and cards from their hand to result the Event.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Point to Point Movement, Role Playing, Set Collection, Variable Player Powers

name: Mesozoic Tales: the board game
description:
"It is a game with many possibilities. Every gameplay is a new story"

Mesozoic Tales is an indie strategy board game for adults, teenagers and children (age 12 and up).

Released in 2013, it has been under production for 7 years. It was inspired by books, films and retro videogames from da 1980's and 1990's generations, capturing the essence from many sources, such as Jurassic Park, Carnosaur, Lost World and Dino Crisis (and others), that filled the memories of many people through cinema, television, the Nintendo, Sega and PlayStation 1.

A remote island hides a secret: an advanced hi-tech dinosaur zoo. However the unpredictable happened and the creatures went loose. The gameplay starts when a group of few people try to put things back in order while the prehistoric beasts are roaming free.

Due to the incident, buildings on the island went out of energy and the players are found in the middle of the map. From there they must fight for survival while reactivating the system in the complexes as described in their Mission Cards.

Complexes are activated by using Access Cards, which can be obtained, or exchanged, at the Access Points in the map.

In case of any assistance players can carry 3 items at hands (Action Cards) - vehicles, guns, medical packs, etc. -, that can be obtained at the Maintenance sheds.

It is possible to play also as dinosaur. Before each turn, players must throw the 'Player Mode' dice to define if he/she will control a carnivorous dinosaur, an herbivore, or a human. In human mode, the player must follow his/her mission normally, but if he/she is playing as dinosaur, he/she can hunt the opponents down and eat them!

It is a game of many possibilities. Every gameplay is a new story: this makes it a terrific fun!
publishers: Colecionadores de Ossos, The Game Crafter, LLC

name: Wash Out: The Game of That's My Line
description:
In Wash Out, players are trying to collect cards that depict the clothes hanging on their clothes line. They need to match both color and style.

The game is for 3-6, but the rules say 4 is best. The game is setup with each player sitting in front of a clothesline they wish to use for the game (these are depicted on the board). Then a number of clothespins equal to the number of players, minus 1, is put in the center of the board.

Each turn players will be looking at their hand of five cards, quickly, and passing one of them to the left after playing any that apply to themselves. The rules state this whole process should be done "as rapidly as possible and may be done as noisily as desired."

When a player has the cards that depicts their clothesline, they quietly remove a clothespin from the center. Then all other players may do so.

This is repeated 5 times and end scoring determines the winner. Scoring is based on clothespins and number of cards completing their clothesline.

name: Step-Chess
description: A chess variant for up to 4 players using a 13x13 pyramidal board. Each side begins with a king and eight pawns. The king always uses normal movement rules; the pawns' movement abilities derives from which level of the pyramid they occupy, with more powerful movement coming from higher (and smaller) levels of the pyramid.

name: Warriors of Darkmyre
description:
Warriors of Darkmyre is a miniatures battle board game playable in forty-five minutes to an hour. Warriors are created from scratch using a character creation system, and may advance through winning deadly battles in the arena. Charts provided for fan reaction as the battle progresses you will win or lose favor with the crowd. Darkmyre arena floors are littered with weapons, gold, and hidden power objects. The real question is will you have time to gather goodies before your opponent is ready to pummel you.

Warriors of Darkmyre features an advancement system that allows players to take their hard earned money from their fights and upgrade to new and more powerful combo attacks, armor, and weapons.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination

name: Durch die Luft mit Zeppelin
description:
A simple 'Roll & Move' game; throw the die and move forward. The race ends by reaching a special space on the track following instructions glued into the lid.

Game should had been published ~1909/10 (definitely later than August 1908), because one of the events printed on the board (space 68) shows the Zeppelin disaster that happened in Echterdingen (Stuttgart).
categories: Aviation / Flight, Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Racing

name: Wanna Buy a Baseball Team Cheap?
description:
From the back of the box:

"What do Aaron Offspeed, Henry Pickoff, Rocky Start, and the Washington Watergates have in common? They are all part of a unique game called Wanna Buy a Baseball Team Cheap?!

"You are the owner of a baseball team. Your goal as owner is to be the first person to buy a complete baseball team at the lowest possible price before any other owner.

"Owners may bid, buy, or trade players. Owners who buy players pay only the stated price. However when players are traded or bid on any price is possible.

"Owners are able to stay in the game provided they have money. They may trade in players to the Profit League bank to get much needed cash.

"A player wins by having the most + points at the end of the game provided no other player has completely purchased a baseball team. Plus points are given for money left at the end of the game. Minus points are given for each player not purchased during the game.

"Wanna Buy a Baseball Team, Cheap?! is not a boring game. It gives the participants plenty of action and decision making."

Self-published by the proprietor of M. Foner's Games Only Emporium in Lemoyne, PA, and distributed through the store. Game seems to be intended to teach mathematics as much as provide a baseball game. A basketball game also exists, Wanna Buy a Basketball Team Cheap? No indication of when the game was originally published exists; some of the art strongly suggests the 1970s, although some parts were apparently printed later, in extant copies.

name: Dragon Quest: Alefgard
description:
A Dragon Quest themed strategy game.

Each player controls a roster of monsters with different movement styles akin to chess. The player to successfully invade their opponents castle wins.
Players roll a six sided die to see how many moves they get on their turn. They may add more moves by spending coins.

The game and rules are entirely japanese, but the full-color rulebook is full of diagrams, illustrations and amusing comics.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Seers: The Old Testament
description:
Seers is a card game themed around Old Testament history. Players are given a hand of cards with various scriptural stories or events on them. One side of each card has just an event name, while the other side contains a Book, Chapter, & Verses for the event, as well as a date of the event. Players will test their knowledge of Biblical history.
Players take turns playing a card into a central chronology, choosing where their card sits relative to other cards. Play can be for correct dates relative to other cards, or for chapter and verse. If a card is playeed correctly, it remains in the timeline. If incorrect, the player must draw a new card, and try again next turn. The first player to be rid of all their cards is victorious.
In addition, correctly playing certain cards may trigger special events that alter the board state. Players hands may be swapped. Cards may be removed from the timeline. A player may be forced to attempt a certain card. A variety of special powers are included.

name: Don't Get Mad Get Evens
description: A trick taking card game with a twist. Players use a dynamic bidding round to determine trump then play their hands following the standard rules for a trick taking card game. There are 4 suits and 6 dual suits to throw in some havoc.

name: WHOA!
description:
Players compete to empty their hands by discarding cards to represent selling horses. On each turn, a player either plays a card matching the horse breed of last discarded card, or plays a "directional card" to change which breed is being played. If the player cannot play a card, she instead draws one from the deck.

In the words of the publisher, "WHOA! is a game of challenge in the marketplace. How many different breeds of horses have you owned over the years? Here's a chance to own more (without the expense) before you finally sell your entire herd. Be the first horseman to do that, and and you win the game of WHOA!"

Like Uno, WHOA! is a commercial version of Crazy Eights, a public domain card game played with a standard deck of playing cards.

name: Pinball The Cardgame
description: Welcome to the wonderful world of flippers, popbumpers and jackpots! Pinball The Cardgame lets you experience the excitement and pleasure of a real pinball machine as a card game. Luck and skills are the main elements of pinball and this card game. Prove that you are a true pinball wizard!
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Point to Point Movement

name: Game of Perga (aka Game of Perge)
description:
A board game used in the ancient civilization of Lycia
(today's Turkey) in Perga (Turkish name: Perge).
No known game mechanic has survived to this day. A dice type movement is most likely.

name: Hatfield vs McCoy "Shotgun Shootout"
description:
Hatfield vs. McCoy "Shotgun Shootout" is a short two player card game (5-10 min) that is spin-off from the traditional
Hatfield vs McCoy card game.

This fast paced game pits three members of both families in a high stakes shootout. The players will go head to head in Rock, Paper, Scissors. The winner targets an opposing family member and makes the other player draw a "trigger" card to determine the fate of that family member.

Play the best "2 out of 3" or "last man standing" format!

name: Sneaky Bunnies
description:
Collect your carrots - but watch out for the farmer.

Players take turns rolling dice to move their bunnies up a path. Upon reaching the end of the path each bunny rolls a different die to determine how many carrots they can look at. If the carrot they pull from the board matches their color they keep it. Upon getting three carrots the player wins. However if the farmer is rolled then the player sends an opponent's bunny back to the start of the path.

name: The Game of Poetical Dominoes
description: Card game from the American Civil War period. The cards feature famous authors and quotes associated with them. Instead of colleciting sets like a regular game of Authors, in this game cards are played to the table domino-fashion (Quote - Author - Quote - Author and so on). The first player to use all their cards, wins.

name: Pay the Price
description:
The game was 'designed' by an AI system developed by researchers from the IT University of Copenhagen in Denmark. The game was created for the NewScientist.com website.

The description below is from the NewScientist.com website (http://www.newscientist.com/article/dn23447-ai-card-game-kno...):

The game begins with the dealer giving nine cards and 99 tokens to each player. The remainder of the deck is placed in the middle of the table.

Each player then makes a mandatory bet of one or more tokens.

Each player then takes one card from the deck and shows it to the other players.

Each player can then take further cards from the deck, if they want, without showing the other players. But for every card taken, the player must discard three cards from their current hand.

Players can repeat the preceding until they have fewer than three cards left.

Once all players are happy with their hand, they reveal their cards. Ace, Jack, King, and Queen are valued as 10. The player with the highest combination wins the round and takes all tokens on the table.

Additional note:
"The player might notice a certain similarity to blackjack," say Font and Mahlmann. Indeed, the rules to blackjack were part of the initial gene pool that seeded the evolutionary run that produced the game. "We believe that the game contains genetic material from blackjack. But we can't be sure. We didn't create the game, after all – our software did."

name: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs Target Game
description:
Nice looking target game. Take turns to fire the gun and shoot the Dwarfs. The ones you knock down score you points;
Sneezy 10
Happy 20
Doc 30
Bashful 40
Sleepy 50
Grumpy 60
Dopey 70
When you finish the game, the one with the most points, wins.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Agony
description:
Agony is a solo word game.
